review_title: Everything I wanted the Fire TV Stick to be
review_text: I love the Chromecast and I have one installed on every TV in my home. Flawless casting YouTube, Netflix, Twitch, etc. I have a 60mb download internet connection and I have used Chromecast with both a wired (you need a separate adapter) and a wireless connection. You can find applications on Android that you can cast just about any video from the internet to a Chromecast. Now if only they would support Amazon Prime Video...EDIT: They've gone and done it, ladies and gentlemen! Google and Amazon have worked it out and now we can cast Prime Video to these devices! I'm in hog heaven!
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2018
author: Dei Su

review_title: Doesn't work the way you might think
review_text: The ad says "Stream from your phone to your TV. Just like that." Lots of articles tell you that the benefit of this over a fire stick is that you don't need an internet connection because you cast right from your phone. Sadly, these things are wrong, you need an internet connection at your house, so it's not like you can just cast from your phone with your unlimited data plan.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2018
author: Marlin Rich

review_title: You can't use Chromecast without internet service and a router.
review_text: I get unlimited internet through my cell phone because I live outside of the city in a small town that doesn't have internet service. So I ordered this with the belief that I could mirror my phone to my TV by getting Chromecast which would be awesome because I could stream Netflix and Amazon straight to my TV... or so I thought. Turns out you cannot stream directly to a TV with Chromecast UNLESS you have internet AND a wi-fi router. This information came directly from Google Chromecast tech support. Why the hell Google would set this up like that I have no idea. Had I known this, I would never have wasted $35 on this device. So please be aware of these facts BEFORE you decide to invest your money in this thing.
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2019
author: James Lockhart

review_title: Be aware - useless in most hotel rooms
review_text: I travel quite a bit and bought Chromecast to be able to use hotel TVs instead of my small phone screen or tablet. Not so fast. At the very end of setup I got a message that Chromecast cannot communicate with my Android phone because of AP (Access Point) Client Isolation feature which prevents WIFI clients on the same router from communicating with each other. It is a security feature commonly used in hotels and other similar situations. Not Google's fault, but they should clearly warn about it as it is very common. Interestingly, in the initial setup Chromecast acts as its own access point and does not need another network, so they could do it differently... Returning it and will check Amazon Fire Stick which needs only one WIFI connection and communicates with its remote via Bluetooth
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2019
author: Kindle Customer

review_title: I Wanted it to send movies, tv, video, etc to my big screen
review_text: I did not realize that the big three, google, apple, and amazon are locked in a death struggle for content and seem to make sure that whatever they control won't work on the other guys product.They all say you can use screen mirroring, but it I went through many you-tube videos and anything else I could find and the best I could do was to get it to work in reverse I could get the nice big picture on my 60 inch to show up on my iphone but not the other way,My suggestion is to decide what you want to watch, see who has a dedicated app for that and buy their device, hoping it will work and knowing it will probably be obsolete in a matter of months, of course if you want to watch something else, you might have to do it again.www this approach is expensive.

With this Chromecast that is not happening. Nice!
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2019
author: sherbert

review_title: It's the perfect device to stream everything from my phone to my TV
review_text: UPDATE: I now have an LG V40 ThinQ with Android 10.0 and the Chromecast is still great. I can send almost anything on my phone to the Chromecast and my TV. It is wonderful.I was looking for a way to send videos from my Android phone to my 2013 Samsung Smart TV. I use Netflix and my TV has an old, outdated version. I also use Prime Video and Kodi which my TV doesn't have. This Chromcast allows me to watch both of these and more on my TV. It was simple to install. I plugged it into my TV's HDMI socket and the power into my home's AC outlet. Then installed Google Home on my phone and followed the instructions. It took some fiddling with the programs but it works great. I read in one of the other reviews that it didn't work plugging the power cable into the TV's USB port. They were right and wrong. The Chromecast uses a 1 amp power supply. My TV has 2 USB ports; a 1 amp and a 0.5 amp. When I used the 1 amp port, it worked the same as plugging it in to an outlet. Now Netflix works simply as per the instructions. However, to get the others to work needs a little ingenuity. I have an HTC 10 phone, but this should work with others. I start Google Home first. Then go into my phone's settings to where the VPN and data exchange settings are. My phone calls the setting "HTC Connect". It tells the phone where to play the media. When you choose it, it lists the Phone, DNLA devices and the Chromecast. When you pick Chromecast, the phone's screen gets played, in real time, on the TV along with the phone. Now, anything you see on your phone gets played on your TV also. It's like using a phone with a 40 inch screen. Along with movies, you can stream music, photos, games, etc. I will be getting a new phone in a few days and will update these instructions when it arrives.UPDATE: I purchased a new LG V40 ThinQ cell phone. And it works with Chromecast just like my HTC phone did. You can stream with supported apps like Netflix or share using settings. The setting is under "Connected Devices". It is called "Screen Sharing" and Chromecast is listed like it was on my HTC. Obviously, I cannot promise that it will work with all phones, but it seems likely that it will.
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2019
author: Dr. M. Helfand

review_text: Works exactly the way you would expect. Much easier to set up than previous generations. Have used Chromecasts as my only tv for years. So easy even my mom and boyfriend's mom can use it.You need:-Your house needs WiFi.-You need a smart phone that is logged onto your wifi (doesn't have to have an active plan).-Your tv needs an available HDMI port.-You need to have (and pay for, if applicable) the apps you want to stream (Youtube, Netflix, Hulu, etc).-10 to 30 minutes of patience and two brain cells.Included:-You can use either a regular wall outlet or your tv's USB port for charging. COMES WITH the charging cable and USB to wall converter box (same as charging a phone).-The ability to cast a phone screen, a phone app, the computer screen, a computer app, a computer file or Power Point.-Step by step setup instructions on your tv screen.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 15, 2019
author: BobTD

review_title: Great for streaming content but needs a phone/computer/Google Home to work
review_text: Really easy to setup using the Google Home app. I have a Google Home mini(smart speaker) that works with this device and allows you to play and pause just by speaking, which is really nice.I like the idea of the Google Chromecast. I think it's a neat idea and it is really reliable (more so than Amazon fire TV). As long as you understand that this IS NOT a standalone device, you should be happy with it. The way it works is-you use your iOS or Android device with a compatible app (look for the cast icon), establish a connection, and then you use your phone as a remote. The Chromecast has no user interface to speak of. You pick what content you want on another device and then cast to the Chromecast. If you are watching a tv series on Netflix for instance, when the episode you are watching finishes, the next one will automatically play. You can also cast from the Chrome web browser which will let you access things like Prime Video which doesn't have casting capabilities in the mobile app. I would recommend using an app over the browser when you can, because it's a smoother experience.There are a few extras like being able to mirror the screen from your mobile device to your tv, if that is something you have a need for. You can also view your google photos in a slideshow while the chromecast is inactive. You can do this in the settings for the chromecast in the google home app. I think this is worth $35, and I would recommend it if you can deal with a slightly less conventional TV/Movie watching experience. After using this a while, I prefer it to an android tv or roku type of OS. I just think they should beef up the Google Assistant features( more like Android TV).Edit: In the time since my original review, Amazon prime video now allows for casting from the iOS and Android mobile apps. Amazon and Google are on better terms now and as a result the fire tv and echo shows now have the YouTube app again and Amazon is selling Google hardware on this site again too. Just wanted to update my review.
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2019
author: Solid Snake

review_text: I had high hopes, only to have them dashed by a crappy product. Immediately upon plug-in, it took about 10 minutes to "load" new software updates, restarting several times. Seriously, brand new product, needs 10 minutes of updates on first plug-in? Then Google wants the Home app on your phone. Ok, load that. Then you need to go through all sorts of really invasive questions and setup that Google says will give a "better experience". B.S. Google only wants info from to you maximize their profit. lastly, there is no real content on the device itself. Just casting from the phone or tablet. And not from every app, just ones that are casting-enabled.I was VERY disappointed. ROKU or Amazon Fire Stick is WAYYYY better. Don't waste your time with this JUNK.
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2019
author: dgal1234

review_title: The best bang for your buck!!!
review_text: I am absolutely delighted with my Google Chromecast (3rd Generation)!Set up is a breeze and very user-friendly. Simply hook up the Google Chromecast (3rd Generation) to your TV and follow the simple install instructions. Then download the app to your phone such as Netflix, Disney +, Amazon Prime Video, etc. ... open the app on your phone ... select the video that you want to watch ... cast it to your TV ... and just sit back and enjoy! Your phone is your remote so you'll want to keep a phone charger nearby.Nothing has to be cracked, hacked, or unlocked. Everything streams from your phone to the TV via your Wi-Fi. It works seamlessly with both iPhone and Android. The resolution is crystal, life like, clear. I absolutely love this product!

review_text: I am not a tech person at all nor do I live in the best area for tech things to work! For starters I ordered a subscription thinking it would work on my tv. In thinking it was a smart tv in all it would work right?? Wrong of course! Well after contacting them I found out about the Google Chromecast and how it will solve my problem. Well after a few failed attempts (which I might add again I am not tech smart) I was able to get everything set up right through my phone and was pretty pleased with myself in doing so. What was really cool was not only was I able to get the subscription, I was able to do a few other things on my tv like add pictures to my screen and a whole bunch of other stuff that I have not even heard of lol. Nothing new I dont deal with watching other streaming channels. Still hoping one day with all this tech stuff they can help people like me who dont live in the city!
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2020
author: Diana L.

review_title: The Chromecast is part of my life now....
review_text: My god... This is so amazing... I love that stupid little puck.Originally I was going to buy an Amazon Firestick buuuut sorry Amazon, Google is connected to everything what did you expect me to do. Don't get me wrong I still own 2 other sticks for my parent's TVs in their bedroom and living room and its very easy to use simply by the use of the remote.Buuuuuut, THE CHROMECAST HAS NO LIMIT. There are TOO many apps you can connect with the casting tech. Its easy to cast, fast, and even better in video quality when compared to your phone. Sometimes a video doesn't immediately load 720p or 1080p on your phone but it's immediately HD when cast. You can turn off your phone and still see whatever you casted last. You can even connect to your TV remote so you can pause and stop casting with your TV remote. Also, that screen mirroring comes in handy every now and then!Honestly I even leave in the ambient mode just for decoration. It's AMAZING. I can watch and cast apps not on my old blue ray not my ps4 or even the Firestick. Switching from Hulu to Netflix to SlingTV to YouTube is INSTANT. No interruptions, very rare buffering and loading is quick with average internet speed. Honestly I really do reccomend this more than the Amazon Firestick. Sorry Amazon, step it up. They BARELY added YouTube as an app on the stick! Here you can even cast your computer screen on the TV! I can't reccomend it enough. Tip: don't buy the 4k version if you dont have a 4k TV.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 16, 2019
author: Dan

review_title: Remote control is STILL a disaster.
review_text: On the positive side, Google has come a long way improving the utterly disgraceful 1st Generation Chromecast's ease of installation. On the downside, they have failed miserably in remote-control (at least where YouTube TV is concerned) of content with your phone. And bear in mind, I have a GOOGLE PHONE.Two infuriating problems:1) The connection between phone and Chromecast fails within minutes of hitting Play --- and the only way you can regain control of your programming is to turn-off YouTube TV (sometimes MULTIPLE times), then HOPE you can regain control. But when you do that, you'll probably lose your place in the program you're watching.2) The FF and Rewind options are uttterly PATHETIC. You either have a 15-sec forward or back option --- both of which respond excrutiatingly slowly --- or you use the slider at the bottom of the screen. And don't even get me started on all the problems that causes --- like, again, total loss of remote control.ALL THAT SAID, if you have a Smart TV, your remote will probably control YouTube TV --- which, apart from the problems mentioned above --- is, in IMO, the best Programming Delivery platform I've ever experienced, including cable and satellite.
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2019
author: francis hare

review_title: Works well with Xfinity mobile app
review_text: There is a lot of software that claims to screencast to an inexpensive TV. Skip them. We wanted to stream as much programming and DVR content to a TV when we are away from our house. Xfinity limits the live broadcasts you can stream. It seems that any programming that you finished recording can be streamed with your mobile app. If Xfinity won’t let you stream it, record it then strean the completed recording. This dongle is very easy to setup using the Google Home App. If your TV has an unused HDMI port the dongle will work for you. You do need good internet service in the area near your TV. There are plenty of youtube videos explaining Chromecasting. Once you have located the Cast button in the Xfinity App, using it is intuitive. There is very little buffering or delay and no problems with picture and voice synch. Youtube streams well using the youtube app. Haven’t yet learned to do general screen mirroring. Suspect I need another app for that.
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2021
author: Stephen Burkhardt

review_text: After cutting the cable I made the Amazon Firestick my streaming device of choice, but casting from my (android) phone never worked- the time to loss of signal was at best a few minutes and very frustrating. Because much of my favorite viewing arrives by phone I finally turned to the cheapest version of the Chromecast as an alternative to the firestick. It does not store apps but it works brilliantly for simply sending my phone screen to the TV. There is never a hiccup in the signal transmission and the video quality is excellent. For this limited purpose you can also use a VPN on your phone if you wish, it does not impede the signal at all. The setup is fairly easy and it has improved my viewing experience enormously. (The built-in screensaver is great too!)

author: Robert H. Buckley

review_title: IT LET ME WATCH DISNEY+ ON MY OLD VIZIO TV!!!! I DID IT ALL FOR BABY YODA!!
review_text: I was VERY frustrated by trying to add the Disney+ app to my 5-year-old Vizio flat-screen TV. I have an iPhone and I have Wi-Fi and I pay my bills and it shouldn't be this hard to add a channel or app to my TV!! I could download the Disney+ app to my iPhone, but I couldn't get it to "cast" or "mirror cast" to my Vizio TV like so many help sites were suggesting. I was seriously thinking I needed to go buy a new TV (ugh) when I saw the Google Chromecast (3rd Generation) on Amazon and it SPECIFICALLY said it would work with the Disney+ app. So I bought it! After reading the instructions (this Chromecast doohickey plugs into an HDMI port on my TV *AND* you have to use the provided electrical cord to ALSO plug it into an outlet at the same time. This is different than the old metal Chromecast I had-and of course lost- years ago.) Then you must download the "Google Home" app on your smart phone and set up your TV from the app. You must have Wi-Fi access, and both your smart phone and your TV must be using the same Wi-Fi. No problem! Then it was easy to "cast" the Disney+ channel from my smart phone to my TV, and now I am very happy watching "The Mandalorian" and baby yoda on a proper large-screen TV. Thank you, Google and Amazon! This was much cheaper than buying a new TV.

review_title: Set Up in Seconds! Works on Old Projector!

My biggest concern with other adapters were restrictions in streaming Netflix or Disney+, after researching this looked to be the best option. Set up is super easy, use the google home app and you’re up and running in no time. It plugs in through hdmi and powers through a usb wall outlet, I was able to power mine directly from the built in usb in the projector. Honestly couldn’t be happier. I only wish there was an option to share my iPhone screen rather than just certain apps, but this works for what we need; a quick seamless solution to watch movies in the backyard without adding too much clutter.

author: Jim

review_title: These are excellent for giving you an additional computer monitor
review_text: Want to use an additional monitor on your computer, but your computer doesn't support an additional monitor? Under the following limited circumstances, you can cast a browser tab to another monitor using this Chromecast:1. The other monitor must support HDMI inputs (so the Chromecast can connect).2. Currently only works with the Google Chrome & Microsoft Edge browsers.3. Once you cast a browser tab to the other monitor, you can minimize the original tab on your computer, giving you screen space. However, in order to interact with the screen on the other monitor, you must un-minimize the original tab & interact there.However, if you just want to start watching a video on the other monitor, this works perfectly.I have eight of these, & they work great.

Now it works great with no issue.

author: Kayce

review_text: The first two generations of the Chromecast had issues with getting too hot, dropping the stream, freezing, etc. This one seems to have fixed those problems. It's warm to the touch when in use, but no more so than any other electronic device (i.e. Roku, Android phone, etc.) would be. it casts/mirrors exactly what is on the original source.Chromecasts don't come with a physical remote; it's simply an intermediary device to translate what you're casting to a format your TV understands. Control of the picture and sound are done by the user on the input device or the end device (i.e. a TV, via its remote).

author: Hector A.

review_text: I finally got around to setting up my Chromecast yesterday (Aug 3, 2020) and I have to say it was pretty straight forward. The device is small and neat. I decided to go with the Chromecast based on research done over several weeks and I had high expectations. However, I observed that it wasn't exactly as anticipated. During several different operations such as mirroring, the response was a bit sluggish and the biggest issue of all is it keeps disconnecting and becomes non-responsive, which forced me to do a reboot. Though that was done, I still experienced the issues. Honestly, it's a nice little device, but there are clearly some issues.It is important to note that during the initial setup the device did perform a automatic update, i would assume that this would correct any possible bugs. Not sure if my device may just be a bad on, but I will watch and see over the next few days, before I draw my conclusion.I will give it some time and test for the next 30 days at which point I will provide an update on my experiences. I would appreciate a feedback from Google as to the reason(s) for the issues.Update: Have been using the device for a few weeks now. However, it has not lived up to my expectations. The main issue is the device keeps losing connection and tends to reboot itself. These actions constantly disrupt my viewing pleasure and as such I am not able to truly enjoy watching movies. As such I have downgraded my rating from 3 stars to 1 star. I strongly believe a refund is in order.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2020
author: SSS

review_title: Very nice and useful, especially if your TV lacks wifi
review_text: This is very useful, so glad I bought it for my TV. I thought it would have a standalone interface (apps and stuff) and it does not, it's just used for casting. This is not negative, just something to point out.My Samsung TVs wireless capabilities stopped working but now I can still stream using the Chromecast. Having Google Assistant is also a plus as you can control volume and TV power if your TV supports HDMI control.I'd say the most important thing to keep in mind is that it doesn't have a stand alone interface like a fire stick for example, instead, your phone and it's apps is the interface.

author: Honest Reviews

review_text: I am impressed with google Chromecast. You can literally project your whole desktop from both windows and mac by choosing to cast feature and selecting the desktop from chrome browser. You can also project an individual tab or file. While casting tab, you can also transfer sound for both mac and windows. While casting desktop, windows transfers sound also but mac does not. So the sound comes from the computer. It naturally works for Chromebooks perfectly for both picture and sound. Don't waste your money on cheap dongles that they promise to work with Miracast and airplay. They are all terrible. From your mobile device, you can cast most applications.

author: R. Stubbs

review_title: If Your On A Budget Get This! If You Can Afford More, Buy The Ultra!
review_text: I truly have mixed feelings about this device...These new notebooks and tablets, are made with such a thin bezel design, that they engineer themselves out from having any HDMI ports! We live in a new age of wireless, I guess everybody hates cords now days. This forces us to buy products like this one, so that we can screencast. Again, tell me whats so wrong with an HDMI cable? My old tablet had one, worked fine, is wireless casting really that much better? Lets find out!So I got a new Dragon Touch Max 10 tablet, naturally it don't come with an HDMI port, figures. So I hooked up this Google Chromecast device to my 1080P IPS 24" monitor. The device tells you on screen to download the Google Home app on your device and to follow the instructions to set it up. While it was technically easy to setup, following the instructions, the process took way longer then I expected.If you took one look at that little device, you would think its not a computer, but you would be wrong. There is a little computer in there, and what is a common thing that all computers like to do? Thats right, install updates. So guess why the process took twice as long as it should? Yep, cause it needed updated. So once that was all done, took me a little bit to learn how to screencast this thing.I was able to screencast Youtube, and Netflix with much success, it loads up to full resolution on screen, looks awesome on my IPS display! Occasionally however, I would notice a slight framerate issue from time to time. More on that later. And then I went into the Google Home app in order to mirror cast my tablet so that everything casts. Well, there is first real bit where I am disappointed.When mirror casting, it does not fill up my 1080P monitor. Its more then likely serving the tablet display's resolution, which is a 1920 *1200 16/10 ratio. Using Droid Info, I discovered the tablet is operating at a refresh rate of 48-herts frequency for display, instead of the typical 60-herts that is used in the US. Since there is no display options to change for screen casting resolutions and refresh rate, I am not able to fix that issue.When playing games, I noticed that the occasional framerate issue I talked about, became total lag, and the bitrate dropped terribly, but this was not the Chromcast devices fault. Turns out, this was my tablets fault! I was connected to my WIFI using the 2.4GHZ frequency, the best signal performance I was getting about 8 feet from my router in direct line of sight, was -30DB. Turns out, that is not enough performance to screencast properly!The good news however, is my tablet is also capable of connecting to my routers 5GHZ protocal. What a game changer that was, switching over to 5GHZ! All the sudden my tablets WIFI performance increased exponentially, and my WIFI performance went off the scale. As soon as I switched over to 5GHZ, all the sudden the Chromecast device was operating better with smooth as glass framerate in video casting, and smoother framerate in gaming as well.The amount of horse power in your device matters too. The more better your mobile device can perform, the better the Chromecast will perform. My new tablet runs a 1.6GHZ Octa core CPU with 3GB RAM, so its no slouch. However, higher end Samsung models and Apple model devices, will more then likely perform better with the Chromecast device, due to more horse power in performance, and in higher resolution and refresh rates.When your not screen casting to the Chromecast, then the Chromecast goes into slideshow mode, where it rotates to images from Google, at a time interval that you can set. And without a doubt, I have seen some of the most incredible images displayed, over the Google Chromecast, as a standbye screensaver solution! However, another bad thing about this device, is it will restart without warning, by its own choosing, for reasons unknown.I figured that I would spend less money and get the 3rd generation model, as the monitor is only 1080P to begin with. But, I can't help but to think, that I would have probably gotten a better experience with screencasting, if I had bought the Ultra model, even though my screen is not 4K. If your on a budget, this 3rd generation model is most certainly an option. However, if you can afford to spend more, go for the Ultra.The Chromecast device also gets very warm, even when not actively screencasting. If your not interested in the slideshow standbye mode when not in use, I would just disconnect the power to the device, to save on your power bill. Also, if your device has less then my devices SPECS for performance, you can forget about wireless screencasting. But you will be better off with a device that exceeds mines SPECS. 4 out of 5 stars!
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 29, 2020

review_title: It Casts, It streams, it’s faster then a sound wave and stronger then an FM radio wave...
review_text: It’s a CHROMECAST! It has no capability nor capacity, nor does it want to, of installing or running apps, it’s selfish that way. Instead it relys on it partner devices, that’s right as shocking as it sounds. It’s Bi- operational preference allows one to (shall I be so bold) use either an Android or iOS device or both but only one at a time, it’s not a progressive as one may think. One must have another device with the apps, or programs installed on the other device. Hit the TV looking button on top of the app or program and viola! Your casting (streaming) to your TV. It’s decadent, it’s the future. It’s only drawback is the restrictions that technology or the programs that YOU don’t allow or allow to be casted. Be carful as casting and or streaming (Depends on what side of the tracks you were born on or currently live) is highly addictive. Some side effects are sore thumbs, getting closer to your loved one(s). Moderation is key unless binge watching is your thing.Easy to install - plug into an empty HDMI port, connect to WiFi, get comfortable with your significant other and or other family member(s), and your done.

review_title: Trade all data on your phone to use Chromecast

Why in the world do they need that access except for collecting data to sell. I chatted with a "help" person after searching multiple times for a way to connect it without the phone download and was told there was no other way to connect it. If I didn't have a phone, I should "borrow" one from someone else. I plan to return it.

author: My name is Howie Consopolis.

review_text: I have a 1st generation chromecast from FIVE years ago and it works just fine. Maybe a little slow at times, but not a big deal.Even though I have Fire TV I couldn't wait on cutting the cord for YouTubeTV and had to get a second chromecast for a different tv. WHAT A WASTE OF TIME AND MONEY.At least once a day I get disconnected in the middle of watching YouTubeTV. I can see Chromecast on my television but it doesn't appear on my phone or PC even though we are on the same WiFi network. This happens constantly and I have to reset (unplug/wait 2 mins/plug back in) allllllll the time. As I type this I am casting video only. No audio. Which is what drove me to return here and finally leave a review. I had been putting it off in hopes that it would get it together, but things have only gotten worse.This thing is a joke. And their suggestions on how to troubleshoot are just as laughable. Yes, my phone, pc and chromecast are all on the same network. No, it isn't my router as EVERYTHING else is working just fine. It's YOU, chromecast.I hate you.Please, Amazon - if you're listening (and I know you are) - acquire access for YouTubeTV already. I'm begging you.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2019

review_text: You can stream almost any subscription streaming service on here and also can CAST YOUR PC'S SCREEN ON THE TV!!! Stream quality is spot on!Now for the FAQs:You need the Google Home application on a MOBILE DEVICE to setup the Chromecast (you cannot get Google Home on your PC) and wifi needs to be enabled + connected on the mobile device.Once the chromecast is setup, the mobile device and others will be able to detect the chromecast device afterwards.Just note:If you are using a streaming service like YouTube, Amazon Prime, etc. Streaming services consume data because the videos are downloading as you play them.Casting a movie or video that is already downloaded on your phone or PC does not consume data because the video is already downloaded.If you want to stream a video from a subscription app such as Amazon Prime, Pluto TV, or YouTube... You have to go INTO those apps to "cast" the videos. NOT from the Google Home app. Those apps will not appear inside the Google Home app and they don't need to.This also applies for PC casting.For the PC, the simplest way to cast is to open up a chrome browser, click on the vertical three dots "..." on the top right of the window, and then chose "Cast..."From there it should pull up the chromecast device and should also give the option to choose to either cast a... file, the desktop, or a specific screen.I highly recommend this if you need a way to project movies on your PC on a TV.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2021

review_text: I recently tried to use Chromecast again, having laid aside mine since I bought Amazon Fire Sticks.But there was some content on my phone not available on the Stick that I wanted to cast on my TV.The whole setup process has changed. Now there is a Google Home app that walks you through it.Long story short: could not get my old dongle to work consistently. Bought this 3rd Gen dongle. Same problems. Sometimes it worked. Most of the time it did not, even with the help of Chromecast customer support.I do not have patience with iffy products. I sent it back. I am not in the market for problems.I picked the old dongle out of the trash. Some day when I am feeling really relaxed, I may try it again.Thank God for the Fire Stick. Not one problem. Ever. You connect it and it is ready to go.
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 23, 2019

review_title: Inconvenient setup. Just a way for Google to collect more data on you.
review_text: In order to setup, you have do download an app on your phone, log into the app using your Gmail account, receive a text verification code, and on, and on... If this was a simple plug-and-play, I would love this. But it's not. It's really just a way for Google to collect more data about you. Furthermore, changing the source input/output is extremely cumbersome. Also, it needs to be plugged into a power source to work. The whole point is for this to be wireless! So disappointing. I am going back to my hassle-free HDMI cable.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2020

review_title: Needs a home internet connection to work, but there's a workaround.
review_text: When you lose your internet connection this device instantly becomes useless. However, there is a workaround that I found by accident. When you lose your home internet connection, turn on your phone's hotspot and name the hotspot the same thing as your home wifi. Chromecast will then try to use your hotspot instead and will connect to the internet via your phone. You can then use casting apps like YouTube, etc. to cast to the Chromecast. Screen mirroring works as well.

review_title: Does not satisfy my travel use case
review_text: My older phones had easy ways to connect video output to HDMI, and then to a large TV screen. My current phone does not support MHL output, and does not have a micro HDMI port, so Chromecast is the ONLY way to display the screen contents of my phone on an alternate screen according to manufacturer's support. And, even then, screen display options are limited to compatible apps. Many newer phones have the same issue, so it seems like phones have regressed in the area of video output rather than progressed.My use case for Chromecast is for travel: I want to display my phone’s screen on a large hotel TV just like my older phones were capable of doing. For example, I want to play downloaded Google Play movies and/or Netflix content on a hotel TV. At home, I use Fire TV sticks since those are standalone devices and a Chromecast at home does not have comparable ease of use since it does not include a remote.Chromecast turns out to be a dead end as an MHL/direct cable replacement because it has the fatal flaw of requiring an Internet connection to display Google Play movies on an alternate screen. Since hotel Internet connections require some browser interaction for each device, you cannot setup Chromecast to use hotel provided Internet.There is a successful way to use two personal devices to setup Chromecast by using your phone as a mobile hotspot, and then connecting the other device to the hotspot and using that to setup Chromecast. After setup, you can access Chromecast via the hotspot phone only and successfully output video to any alternate screen with HDMI input. Unfortunately, that does not meet my use case because Chromecast in this configuration consumes limited data classified as “mobile hotspot:” it’s not simply the Phone’s video output from an unlimited data plan. Chromecast also, and astonishingly, ignores an already downloaded Google Play movie and streams it again using the limited hotspot data, so pre-downloading is not a viable workaround.Using a local Wifi router in a hotel also fails: you can do Chromecast setup, but media features such as Google Play movies, even those already fully downloaded, will not play since the local router does not have an Internet connection.I often carry a Chromebook with HDMI out with me while traveling, and Google Play does allow movie downloads on that so you can download movies in advance using the lower “free” tier of hotel wifi rather than rely on hotel low tier direct streaming only. A Chromebook, although more expensive, succeeds at being a much more useful media casting device to a hotel TV than Chromecast. I will be returning the Chromecast since it does little more than waste my time.
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 24, 2019
author: AnikaGSD

review_title: Doesn't work reliably mirroring phones;Mirrors Chrome browser on laptops;Full circle of disappointme
review_text: (written by husband of account holder) Didn't like the way that only a single wi-fi network is saved on the device at a time. After my wife was able to easily use the Chromecast successfully at home to stream a movie from a laptop I tried to use it at church to mirror my phone, a Pixel 4XL. This required resetting the device(as I was not at home when I wanted to reconfigure it) to recognize a wireless network at church. Then things got worse - the device doesn't seem to work on wireless networks with a captive portal.So... I borrowed my wife's phone(a Pixel 4a) to create a Wi-Fi hotspot(the plan was to mirror from my own Pixel 4XL) and was able to reconfigure the Chromecast to work on the hotspot. Good to go, right?At that point I was able to successfully change the screensaver images to a gallery on my phone. Looking good at this point, it seems.Sunday school class starts and I connect to the Chromecast(yay!) and try to start the mirroring... and nothing. No error message. Phone indicates the Chromecast is connected so I try again - nothing appears on the large display the HDMI is plugged into other than the screensaver that was earlier configured.I disconnect my phone from the Chromecast, reconnect to the Chromecast, and attempt to mirror my phone's display again. Nothing - just the screensaver. At this point I revert to using the chalkboard and pen and paper to facilitate the class discussion.Ultimately a disappointment, made even worse by the fact that previously at home I was able to successfully mirror my Pixel 4XL to our TV there. I'm sure there are troubleshooting steps I overlooked, but I just wanted this thing to quickly and easily work and felt that it would work great since I was using all Google branded products. Not so. Was about to return it but my wife suggested to use the laptop instead next time. I guess that'll work. Then again, so would running an HDMI cord straight from the laptop, or buying an HDMI wireless transmitter - wait, wasn't that essentially why I bought the Chromecast in the first place? <U+0001F61E>
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2021

review_text: I bought this with intentions of replacing the need for my long and winding HDMI cable, which I feed from my desktop computer to my television on the other side of the room. Essentially, I pull up various streaming services on the computer and then watch them on the TV, but in order to pause, rewind, or change videos, I have to get up and sit at the computer for a bit. It's a pain in the butt, however it's worked for me flawlessly for well over a year now. I had hoped to be able to cast TV, music, and videos from other devices (phone, laptop, tablet) to the Google Chromecast and save myself a few steps back and forth.Unfortunately, my only truly compatible device is my Android phone which, due to storage space issues I use for nothing, so the control features built into this product are useless to me, and I don't have any other Google Home products so being able to call out voice controls isn't something I can benefit from either. When screen-mirroring and casting from my other devices (which was my primary goal anyway), the connection is absolute garbage. The video itself comes through in oddly poor quality, the audio is choppy and robotic, and the stream often lags despite having excellent high-speed internet in my home. I'm returning this thing, and will try an Amazon firestick instead. At least it comes with a real remote.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2020

review_text: I've used an earlier version of the Chromecast for years. It still works well. I also have the newer 3rd generation, and it works great.I love bringing Chromecasts when I travel. It's great to be able to watch the Apps that I want on (almost) any TV that I want. I've used Chromecasts when I traveled to other countries, and it's a great way to share photos, videos and music from my phone/tablet while visiting family/friends. I've also gifted Chromecasts with friends/family I've stayed with by installing it on their TV for them. It works well, as long as they have a free HDMI port on their TV and a USB power source. (It uses a Micro USB port for power.) They're usually amazed that they can now watch YouTube on their TV.Chromecasts, I've found, may be available in other countries, but they are often more expensive and not as widely used. I always bring at least one with me. For me, it's a must-have item for travel.

review_title: Can even be used with your cellular hotspot
review_text: I don't have an internet connection where I live yet I stream music, Prime Video, Hulu live, and Netflix on my HDTV using the Chromecast device. This is a great tool in your arsenal for cord cutting. I have 40Gigs of 4GLte hotspot a month between two smartphones and this is enough for me to stream and binge watch while at home or away.1) Simply download the Google Home app from the Google play store to any android device (I've used this app on my android tablets and phones with hotspots. My tablet only has a 3GLte hotspot and that's ok for streaming music but too sluggish for streaming high quality video). You use the Home app on the device to set up and name the Chromecast device (ex: ChromeLvRm, ChromeMBR, etc). This name is what shows up as attached to your wifi hotspot whenever you turn the hotspot on while in range of the Chromecast. This setup is a one time thing per Chromecast device. Once it's set up, you are good to go.2) use your tv remote control to switch your input to what ever HDMI you have attached the Chromecast to.3) (Unlike the Amazon firetv, Chromecast has no apps. The apps are on the device you cast from to the Chromecast device.) Then you use your device to play your streaming app (Hulu, Netflix, etc). When the video starts, you will see the casting symbol in the upper right corner of the video. Press this and you're casting to your Chromecast/HDTV. You use your device to pause, play, control volume, end casting, etc. Your device acts like the remote control.So to recap: you only need three things, your HDTV with HDMI connection, your device with the Google Home and streaming apps you've obtained from the Google play store, and your mobile hotspot...

author: Greg Weaver

review_title: Does not do what I expected
review_text: Don' waste your time and money on this product. I bought this with the understanding that it lets me cast "any media" from any app on my iPhone -- especially from within Safari or Google Chrome browser apps -- to my TV. I found in great disappointment that this product can NOT do that! All it can do is let you cast media from a specific "limited" number of channels, like Hulu, YouTube, Netflix, and a few others to your TV. But I could already access those channels and many more directly from my Roku streaming device beautifully. Talking to the ChromeCast Tech. Support, I found that the only way one can cast media from Safari/Chrome to a TV via the Chromecast is by buying one of several 3rd-party apps. I gave that a try, but those apps (at least the free version) bombarded me with pop-ups and long commercials, and then cast media at low resolution with lots of buffering stops along the way. Absolutely horrible! I wiped those apps from my iPhone and returned the ChromeCast the next day.Doing a little research online, I found that my wonderful Roku streaming device can elegantly link to the built-in AirPlay on my iPhone and iPad to "mirror" anything on the phone's display to the TV set. Bingo! That is exactly what I needed. Now, if you have an Android smart phone or tablet, things might work a little better for you (?).

review_title: Offers no advantage over using an old laptop as streamer; my TV already accepted Mirroring
review_text: The Chromecast works as described. I was expecting more; I should have researched the product more completely. I've been using an old lap top as a streamer for the last few years. It's plugged into the HDMI of our 2013-era smart TV. It works fine for streaming Netflix, Amazon Prime Video, YouTube, etc. I've gotten frustrated with the slowness of the lap top's start up and it's Blue Tooth connectivity seems hit or miss - we control it via a Blue Tooth keyboard and mouse that reside on the couch. Time to up date, I figured. I thought the ChromeCast would provide a more seemless way to stream those services. It's really not. Operating the ChromeCast is more fiddly than I'd hoped. And it essentially has you mirroring your smartphone or tablet to the TV screen via the ChromeCast. I can already mirror the screen of my smart phone or tablet from those three streaming services to the TV w/out the ChromeCast. It's also kind of fiddly. Both that method and the ChromeCast seemed less/not more convenient than using the old slow-starting laptop. So, there you have it. Old slow-starting laptop is a better solution for us. I can see the ChromeCast being perfect for someone with a TV that doesn't accept mirroring. And it was only $19.

review_title: Good for batting practice, and that's it.
review_text: I bought this because I was watching more and more youtube at home but didn't want to deal with a smart tv interface. My mistake.Right out of the box this thing was finicky. I had multiple instances where when I tried to cast, the chromecast wouldn't be findable, and I then had to factory reset the whole thing. Even then, often the setup wizard would then inform me that I wasn't on the same wifi and I would then have to repeat. Google's customer service for this item is near worthless. Finally this morning I had had enough - I have thirty minutes I could be watching something, thing won't connect. Fine. Factory reset? Nope, didn't take bub, better do it again. After about five minutes of this thing wasting more of my time, I took it out back for some batting practice. Swing one, strike. Swing two, strike. Swing three - home run! And I say this with complete sincerity, watching that busted piece of junk fly over my fence and away is the only enjoyment I ever received.

review_text: While this device does the one thing it does okay, that one thing isn't worth much. It streams from your phone to your tv and really nothing else. The picture quality is good, but the sound is horrible, and you cannot control anything from the tv. And for what it does, there really isn't much use: I can stream all the services listed on the box (youtube, netflix, prime, etc.) with my tv with much better results and some actual control, so why would I bother projecting my phone to the tv? I bought it because I was trying to find a way to stream my video library from my pc (I've had inconsistent results with other methods), but despite the online sources that say otherwise, it doesn't do that. It only streams the chrome browser to the tv, which I don't have any use for. I suppose I could rig up chrome to play the videos somehow, but again I would have to control it from my pc, eliminating the usefulness of the device for that purpose.

author: Edward p.

review_text: Use it solely to stream movies and such from my phone. Originally was using the screen beam mini 2 but find the Google Chromecast more dependable. Have sound/audio issues with the other device that seems to occur because it is very hot to the touch after a short period of time when in use. Went through 4 replacements and all had that issue. The Google Chromecast, no such issue. Had to replace one chromecast after about 6 months, it kept dropping the connection for no reason.I do find the screenbeam setup a lot easier than the Google Chromecast. With the Screenbeam at a hotel there was no special setup required, just plug in the hdmi port and begin streaming. I haven't figured out the Google chromecast setup outside the home yet, it seems to want you to load something when in a different location. That's a slight negative for me. Will probably call support one day. Also, with Google chromecast some streaming services don't show the movie playing on your phone and TV together. It's a little inconvenient when you want to pause, FF or rewind. That was never the case with the screenbeam. Finally, the replacement of one Google chromecast to another requires a complete separate setup and naming convention. Find that a bit bothersome. Not the case with the screenbeam.All in all, for Quality and Reliability I love, love, love the Google chromecast device.

review_title: Important to Know the Difference Between Casting and Mirroring
review_text: I thought I could get away with using this to play downloaded Netflix content from my phone to the tv without an internet connection. You need an internet connection for this to work, however, and this is where the product description is misleading. They say that you need a wifi network for this to work, but they need to say that you need a wifi network that is connected to the internet. Two different things. This is a casting device, which means it uses the internet to look up and stream content that your phone directs it to. It does not take the content from your phone and put it on the screen. Hopefully this can help someone with similar desires and circumstances to not waste $30.

review_text: Before discovering the Chromecast I had been using my xbox one for YouTube, Hulu, Netflix, etc... The downfall to using the xbox for streaming services, is that you have to rely on the xbox network being up which has had some serious downtime in the past. Also occasionally the app on the xbox would get an update and not just not work.With the Chromecast all you need to worry about is your network and your connected device. That being said, not all phones are created equal, and some phones will struggle more than others.It's just made streaming more convenient. You can pause, fast forward, rewind, and even change the volume, all from your phone. People connected to your network can also control the Chromecast, with that it'd be nice to see a lock feature to keep others from disturbing your stream.Overall I really enjoy the Chromecast and I have one on each of my tv's in my place. I highly recommend getting one.

review_text: This is my third Chromecast. The first two were 1st gen units, one of which I still use. On the other 1st gen unit the HDMI port became bent and unusable. This new design seems much more durable. The HDMI port is on a cable, not built directly into the dongle. I decided to buy another Chromecast when I read Amazon Prime Video would no longer be supported on our old Wii U.Streaming with the Chromecast is extremely simple if you have an Android phone. I don't have any Apple devices, so I can't attest to how it works with iPhone. Start out by plugging the Chromecast into the HDMI port on your TV and hook up the USB power cable either to a wall plug using the included wall-wart adapter, or to the USB port on the TV. I used the port on the TV to reduce cable clutter. Turn on the TV and switch the appropriate HDMI port, and you should see the Chromecast startup screen. Download the Google Home app on your phone and have it search for devices. Tell the Chromecast which network to connect to and give it the password.Once it's connected to the network, you can select the cast icon in programs that support it, such as Prime Video, Youtube, Netflix, and many others. Video quality probably depends on your network. On mine, I have no problem with 1080p HD video. This version of the Chromecast doesn't support 4K, you need the Chromecast Ultra for that, but my TV doesn't support it either, so I just went with the non-Ultra unit. If an app doesn't support streaming, you can always share your phone's screen using the Home app, then run your app and it will be mirrored to the Chromecast. The quality isn't as good as an app that natively supports casting, but it works. I believe Chrome on a PC can cast as well, but I haven't tried that.

review_title: Using it to stream a VR feed from the phone
review_text: It's fast and easy to set up. Just plug in. Go to the web address shown on the screen. Download. Pick your Google acct, do the directed walk-through and bam! You can now stream any content you can see on your phone, from your phone, tablet, etc. to the TV w this device.Because we are streaming an Oculus VR, we had a couple extra steps. Go into the Oculus app, select the headset, then tell it to search for the new device (We named ours Living Room TV), select that, then select "Start" and we were off.Unlike other things we have tried, it streams fast enough to stay in sync with fast games like Beat Saber.We don't have the Wifi 6 either. Even though we have read it helps if the stream is a little slow, no problems.One day, when we can safely have friends over for gatherings, we will be able to set them up on the headset, then everyone can watch them battle robots, walk on the surface of Mars or just slice blocks in time to music.Amazing how well such an inexpensive little device works.(We read that if you don't have a 4k TV, buying the 4K version of this is a waste of money since it won't stream any faster, but you should do your own research. We are happy with this device just as it is on our normal HD TV)

Once I nearly quit it decided to randomly start working and now it does what I wanted it to, so maybe I should give the device a better rating and give the app 1 star, but that wouldn't be reflective of my experience so whatever. I mean, this is GOOGLE we are talking about. And a pretty simple task that's built in to samsung TVs. Get your #### together, google. I've had off brand smart outlets with better app control.

review_text: I could probably have learned that I had no use for this device without buying it, but I made (incorrect) assumptions about its utility. It does NOT work on Windows, Win10 at least but probably no version. I was able to cast from an Android phone, only a portrait view, onto my TV. Why would I want a tiny portrait view of anything on my TV? What I wanted, and thought I was getting, was a device that would Cast ANY screen from my PC to the big TV. That is, even if that screen did not have the cast icon. I can run a 50 ft HDMI cable from a PC to a TV, I wanted a wireless version of that cable, but Chromecast is not it.My phone is Samsung Galaxy S8+, running Android 9. Chromecast kept disconnecting, and I got a message (do not remember from where...Chromecast app?) saying "Your phone is not optimized for chromecast mirroring." Maybe it was Chromecast support who told me a gimmick to keep from disconnecting:On phone, turn off Mic Permissions, force close all apps, turn on Mic Permissions again.Any app that does have a cast icon will cast perfectly in HD from PC to TV using Roku. Roku's only shortcoming is needing that cast icon. There is apparently a component that is missing from Win10, that keeps me from sending a browser page withOUT the cast icon, to Roku. Something like "miramax" or similar. Something that used to exist but no longer does, it seems.

review_text: Setup was easy enough. The Google Home app is as intrusive as anything Google does, with the usual Google crap but it walked me through set up quickly and clearly. I set it up on my just-retired phone. I can check my mail, which takes me out of wifi range, while pausing my movie. Leave it paused too long, though, (maybe after 10 minutes or so) and plan on starting your connection over from scratch. A few problems. Sometimes the pause button is hard to find. Sometimes it's on the locked screen, sometimes you have to hit the unlock button, sometimes I have to turn the phone on. (As in, unlock the phone) Your connection to the web site may time out, while the content is still streaming through the unit. If you want to backtrack or fast forward, that can be a pain. I ran it all day yesterday, (Mostly youtube music, with movies and shows interspersed) and it spontaneously rebooted late at night. Unit and plug were warmer than I like to see, too.You don't actually mirror your phone screen on the tv screen, but if the media has the little "cast" icon, you can play it on the tv. Some sites, you have to go to full screen on your phone for the icon to appear. Prime, for example, will play series shows without interruption, but when a movie ends, I have to find the next one on the phone.It's not perfect, but it does work.They say to control the volume with the phone volume control, but the control on the tv works just fine.

review_text: It has been a few years since I installed the first Chromecast devices, and I was very pleased to find the set up on the new ones is much smoother and easier than the originals. So far works great.BTW, they do still come with a power supply that uses a standard USB cable, and a cable is included. So there is no need to order a shorter cable if your TV has a USB connection (most do). You can just take the power from there, and wrap up the extra cable to your taste. I am told that on newer TVs, if the Chromecast has its own power source, the TV can detect it if you begin casting and turn on automatically. I didn't need that, so I haven't tried it, but it won't work if the Chromecast is being powered from the TV's USB jack.

review_text: Purchased to use with Oculus Quest 2 VR headset. When it works, there's a minimum 1/2 second to 3/4 second lag behind what player sees. Apparently this is common, but you won't find it anywhere in the advertising brochure. It's designed more to stream highly-buffered movie content than extremely interactive gaming. This may be ok for casual showing to grandma, but makes it impossible for viewers to really "connect" what they see on screen with what the gamer did a second ago.Half the time it won't connect, or drops after a few seconds. Would not recommend for fast-paced interactive video games. The Oculus Quest 2 can also cast via Bluetooth to phone but this was also fairly laggy. If you really want to see what your Oculus gamer sees, skip the Chromecast and instead cast via WiFi to a PC (which worked with minimal-but-acceptable lag).

author: Gilbert Del Orbe

review_title: Not worth it for my purposes (Updated)
review_text: UPDATED: Given an extra star because apparently switching to the 2.4GHz network has really made a difference in the reliability. It took a few uses, for some reason, for it to settle down, but it certainly has. If you're having problems, definitely switch to the 2.4GHz network. It's still a bit frustrating, and I'd still consider going Fire Stick next time around.I purchased this to stream videos from a browser tab on my PC to a TV just across the room. Should be simple, right? Nope. It will work fine for a few minutes, maybe even enough to watch a full period of hockey, but will invariably freeze up, disconnect, and tell me the source is not supported until I restart the TV. Sometimes it happens when I'm doing other browsing on the PC, sometimes it will happen even when I just leave it alone. I've tried connecting the Chromecast to both my 5GHz and my 2.4GHz networks, the 2.4GHz seems to be better but it also got off to a rough start and now stutters on occasion. We'll see if this holds up.When it's working, the picture and sound quality are just fine. I haven't really used the Hulu streaming option so maybe it's more reliable for that, and for some reason I cannot look my Netflix account to the Chromecast, but neither of those options are why I bought the Chromecast. If it continues to be a problem I will certainly invest in a Fire Stick instead.

review_title: easy to hook up....not easy to use. Buy another product that actually comes with instructions.
review_text: Simple connection....simple downloading of app....simple set up. The only missing missing: Instructions for how to use the darn thing after it's hooked up. After an hour of trying....all I can get is Card Sharks on Sling (which I don't even prescribe to so it must be a trial membership....which I actually declined.) I have Hulu. I linked Hulu and submitted my email,PW, and authentication. Now there is nothing that guides me to watch it. There is a broadcast button and media button....tried both and get nowhere. I'm ready to send this back and try another product. NO INSTRUCTIONS beyond connecting it, switching TV input, and set up. No instructions for actually using. There is a "watch TV Live" option that does nothing except play one show. (Great screen saver images though. ) What a joke. I have the TV hooked up to a Hardan Kardon A/V receiver, BOSE 401s, and a Pinnacle Sub Amp. The only thing that will play is card sharks game show and the sound is atrocious. So much feedback and squeaking. SMH.

review_title: Bad. Bad. Bad. Back it goes.
review_text: Bad interface. This is a good idea drowning under several layers of corporate "enhancements". Apparently the Gen 1 devices were pretty handy. This just plain isn't and it has to do with Google's "integration" - that looks like a first year coding project.Requires Google Home and installs Google Go as well. Device throws configuration errors and chain of Google software "control" apps fails most of the time. (Wifi etc. fine - repeated diagnostics/restart etc. several times). Even got what looked like a linux configuration failure once. Works poorly from Chromebook, works...oddly...from Android tablets (strange resolutions/orientation). Not at all from Android phone. No bueno.You can think what you like about Google's "integration" of all your information around this thing but I did notice that it kept the wifi passwords in memory even after a hard reset.This is a lot of work to outdo the $10 cable I'm going to use instead.

review_title: DOES NOT WORK RELIABLY FOR DESKTOP SCREENCASTING
review_text: Admittedly I probably should have done a little more research before purchasing. If I had done this, I would have discovered that the basic Chromecast has a documented bug/defect when it comes to screen casting a desktop from a Chromebook or other computer devices. If there is little as a 1ms buffering of the image, the Chromecast stops accepting the screencast input, and simply displays a static image of the last view before the buffering event. And since my SOLE reason for purchasing a Chromecast was that it was supposed to fully support screen casting from a Chromebook, as opposed to the 3 Firesticks we already own/use, which won't. To be honest, Google's claims that you can indeed use the Chromecast for this type of use is borderline, if not outright deceptive, SINCE IT DOES NOT WORK RELIABLY.We will be returning this for a refund.UPDATE: Returning it was quick and easy with Amazon.

review_text: Reasons I wanted this: 1) I'll be living in a hotel room away from home for a long time and want to cast from my phone to a TV and 2) Home internet is down and want to cast my stuff from phone to TV.1) Doesn't work on hotel WiFi because for security purposes hotels don't let devices see each other so chromecast and phone don't see each other. Awesome hotel IT made me my own network SSID so my devices can see each other, still didn't work. Tried putting chromecast on my phone hotspot. It got internet but usually couldn't cast.2) home internet is down for weeks. Tried the hotspot off my phone again. HBO app could cast to it for 2 days and 3rd day it couldn't (nothing changed). Tried connecting my phone and chromecast to husband's hotspot so they're on same wifi, still doesn't work.Summary: This thing and the Home app are useless and frustrating.If you want a streaming device, get an Amazon Fire stick.

review_title: When signal fails movie starts back at the beginning
review_text: Maybe Google's QC has failed on this product or I was extremely unlucky and got the only partially functioning one from the factory.I though it would be nice to go wireless, but this is not the product to do it. I was able to get the device to see my computer and I could start watching a movie, but within 30 - 90 seconds it would slow down, then cut off the movie completely. A few seconds later the movie would come back, but it would start from the beginning. This is not acceptable.I could never get the device to play anything from my Google branded Pixel phone. If Google can't get their devices to talk to each-other, I can't imagine what it would be like if you did not have a Google phone?!I've spent many hours looking at the help communities and reading posts about this device. There is so much out there on how to troubleshoot this device. I guess if there is that much information it means a LOT of people are having problems.One piece of advice was to make sure your phone/computer is within 5 feet of the Chromecast (i tried it and it still would not work)! Then why not just buy a cable! I mean, really... If your phone/computer has to be on the same piece of furniture as the TV, then what is this really for?I am retuning this to buy a 15 foot cable for half the price and can still have my computer on my lap while I stream movies to my TV.

review_text: My neighbor turned me onto to this device. He brought his over and we plugged it in, got it all set up and I was able to bring up my Google photos from iPhone 11 to our Samsung smart TV in a slideshow format. I then bought one after my neighbor’s and I can’t for the life of me get it to work. It won’t slideshow the pics automatically. I have to swipe my iPhone screen to see it on the TV. Plus, it won’t do videos from your phone unless I’m doing it wrong. Again, these large companies have very poor support service. I went out and did a search and found an app called Replica and guess what, in 3 steps I was able to watch my homemade iMovies and my pictures from my iPhone to my TV. Worked great. So maybe it was just me but I find Google and Apple don’t always “talk”, if you know what I mean.

review_title: Way Way Way better than 2d gen APPLE TV
review_text: I will say this is way better than my second gen. Apple TV! The Apple is a piece of crap...Most newer smart tvs and smart phones can mirror directly to each other w/o the Google device, but the Google makes it a little easier to connect.Chrome cast is not perfect, sometimes when using my phone to cast from, it does not find the TV to pair with. You need to restart your phone or the Google device, then it works. Make sure tv and phone are using the same WiFi name.The streaming is good, very little if any skipping. The Apple skips often and I can't tolerate it.So I'll give the Google 3 stars because it's not quite as user friendly as I thought it would be.The other thing I dislike about the set up is you need to get the "Google home app" for the install, it wants to access your personal infoOn your phone....I just want to mirror what's on my phone!My solution was to download the app, then skip all the offer prompts it allows u to get through the set up, then uninstall the app from the phone. I set the tv to "source" where the Chromecast is plugged into, then find the cast icon on your phone. Works every time.I can't comment on tech support, never used them.

review_title: Requires a Google Home invasion, and cannot be turned off.
review_text: It works. Sort of.1. You have to install Google Home on anything you want to stream to it, even if you don't have any other Google Home devices. That means computers, phones and pads.2. Link is very slow to start. And I've had it fail in the middle of streaming a show and had to re-connect through Google Home on my phone. I have very fast, clean internet - there is no excuse for it to disconnect.3. It cannot be turned off. It has no sleep mode. It SUCKS power whenever it is plugged into something and STREAMS a repetitive set of images. My power bill went up $10 the first month. I unplugged it from the power, and it went back down. I can't gage how much bandwidth it stole. So I have to leave it unplugged when I'm not using it, which means I have to reconnect it when I want to use it.

review_text: Using with a laptop and Samsung GS7. Using with the phone is great. I simply open amazon prime video app, then cast direct from my phone to my TV. Plays smoothly as on my phone. I also had success casting an embedded streaming video in chrome (Android). I can still use my phone for other things including streaming other media (tune in radio). I tried casting my desktop, and it worked, but not as smoothly. Another negative about this use was, the desktop also showed the show, which was a bit distracting compared to using the phone. There may be another way?Like the title says, I've ummed and ahhed about the value of something like this since I saw my friend use one to cast kids shows on Netflix, to their play room TV in the basement, from the kitchen. I've been using a laptop connected to the TV via HDMI, which drops out now as the laptop gets old and the port wears out. I'm going to hold off replacing the laptop now. :) I have a Lenovo P10 tablet coming tomorrow so think that'll replace my laptop as a media device. My laptop is getting less and less use these days!I only have a 42" TV so got the non 4k version. I figured if I get a bigger TV I'll get the ultra for that. But this one is perfect for me right now.

review_title: Learn in advance. Instructions Useless! Great Product, even though the setup was a nightmare!
review_text: High quality product. Comes with a Long USB Cable and Wall Outlet Plug (Nice), Sturdy HDMI Cable on the device. It fit nicely behind the TV, and the included USB cable was long enough to reach the wall outlet. Afte some cable management, it was all nice and neatThe reason I gave it a 1 star review:...the enclosed instructions are useless. I had to refer to a you-tube video in order to get it working. Once I found a video to get it working, it worked fine. Really angry that there was not a complete set of instructions included. Also, the help page they referenced gave a 404 page not found error. So the online help was not available. If you are not tech smart, do your research before you buy. This should include any instructional videos you can find on you-tube. Very poor planning by google on this one. People should not have to search for a how-to in order to get this item to connect and work.

review_text: This is useless for me. Unfortunately, I didn't realize that the problems I was having were due to my chromecast rather than my wifi until I used my chromecast in another house, beyond the return period. I have had all types of problems. First, the video I was casting would frequently freeze or stutter. Like I said, I thought this was just due to my internet. but, when I finally got away from sheltering in place, and went to another location, I realized that the problem is the chromecast, not my internet. Today, I tried to watch an online film festival. Nope. The film won't play when I'm trying to cast it, but it works perfectly if I just play it on my computer. the minute I try to cast it, the movie stops. I can't get it to play until I stop casting. The other day, a video just froze, and the image stayed on my television. I had to unplug the chromecast and turn the television off and back on to get rid of the frozen image. Just stopping casting did nothing. Unfortunately, I'm now beyond the return date, so I have a useless piece of tech.

I clicked that and all HDMI ports were shown, and HDMI 3 was highlighted,with my TV remote, I clicked that and Amazon Prime Video appeared in all its glory.Fire Stick works. Follow these steps!For Netflix I have to sign in again, because I am using Fire Stick on a different TV.Great, now I am going to return ChromeCast.

review_title: Sound becomes very distorted after a while...
review_text: We bought a 3rd generation chromecast to replace a 1st gen model thinking it was an improvement but while the picture quality is great, the sound will become very distorted while watching a movie - so much that it becomes unwatchable. This only happens after 20-30 minutes of continuous streaming and the only way to reset the sound is to hit the "back 30 seconds" button. This happens in all streaming apps so it not the app but is the chromecast causing it. Sometimes it fixes it for another 10-20 minutes, sometimes less. It doesn't do it watching shorter streams like TV shows with commercial breaks, only long, uninterrupted streams. Almost like it overheats. We've ordered a warranty replacement from Amazon and will try it out but if this one is a dud I guess we'll return it and try another casting device. Nice work, Google.

review_text: I'm a longtime Chromecast/Google ecosystem user. We bought our first one in 2013 and it still works! We got a replacement unit a few years ago that's been flaky. This newest replacement has not been an improvement. When we cast from YouTube specifically, which accounts for a lot of our daily watching, the audio cuts out for 1-2 seconds every 10-15 seconds or so. We've tried alternate HDMI ports and fiddling with the settings but no luck. My partner has no issues with audio when casting from her device. We both have Pixel phones. We're all-in on Google but it doesn't "just work" as you might imagine the Apple ecosystem would. Disappointing to have quality decrease in the seven years we've been Chromecast users -- we have 3 Chromecast devices in 3 separate rooms and the first one we bought in 2013 has been the best.

Hardware vendors should all learn from this. The only downside is it requires a mobile device ... not uncommon today but something to be wary off for some still-phoneless friends.The 6' USB Cable means for one of my TVs it's on with the TV is, off when the TV is off. Nice touch. For the other one the USB Adapter plugs into the same power outlet so one casting, it just continues. For anyone on a metered connection, be aware that you must stop casting to stop streaming.It's smaller than I thought but that's probably ok. It hangs behind my TV so now I have wireless casting for a clean living room setup.I can't cast from Chrome on iOS.I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it for over-the-top TV like Disney+ or YouTubeTV viewers. review_text: Consider your internet and WiFi speed if planning to stream video from let's say a computer to a TV. Your network needs to be able to handle the stream coming from your provider and then at the same time re-send it to the Chromecast device, essentially doubling the traffic on your home network. In my case the result was unacceptably jerky video. This isn't a problem with the Chromecast device itself, it's a network capacity issue, but be aware of what might happen. If you're just sending a PowerPoint presentation or showing photos, for example, it would work great, although there is a tiny delay between the source and the TV that can make navigating with a mouse while looking at the slightly-delayed screen image on the TV difficult. Still better than dealing with a cable though.

review_title: This works out exactly as I hoped! A lot of instructions and tutorials to go through, but worth it!
review_text: I was having trouble trying to get my HDMI to VGA adapter working properly to connect my TV to the Internet, so instead I opted for this Chromecast purchase. I plug it into the HDMI on my TV and then install the Chromecast app and Google Home app on my iPhone to connect. Your TV has to be directly connected to the internet of course for this to work properly and your phone must be connected to the same WiFi in your house. Once you have those all updated, you then download the apps to your phone: Netflix, Hulu, Disney+, Peacock etc. to properly cast them to your TV. Your apps all need to be also updated on your TV Cast app (The app needs to know about your streaming apps... I know, all lays it on a bit thick). Once you have downloaded all that properly, you should be able to cast whatever your phone is about to play (instead of it playing on your cell phone) and then hit the cast button in the top right corner of the Netflix app, Hulu app, Disney+app, Peacock and etc apps to send the stream to your TV instead. Voila! Your TV is streaming! This works especially well for older smart TVs that work just fine, but don't quite have Disney+ because that service is too new to show up in your TV's app store. The Chromecast is like an additional gadget to get an upgrade.Hope this all made sense and your Chromecast works as well as mine does on all my streaming services. -G

review_text: For about three weeks after I bought this it did what it said: I could open up youtube on my browser, start a video, and cast to my TV where it would play as if it were cable. All of a sudden it stopped doing that, and no amount of reseting or power cycling will change it. If I hit the cast button on my browser (Chrome) it opens up a youtube interface on the TV, which allows me to look through my library or search for things using the clunkiest search function in history (well done Google!). What it doesn't do is simply play the video I was watching on my browser. I have to add the video to a list and then get to it through the clunky interface on the TV.As if that isn't bad enough, the casting process will occasionally simply stop and nothing will get it going again. I have to cycle the power on the device, but that means I lose my place in the video and even the fact that I was watching that particular video, and need to go back to square one with finding it in one of my lists or searching for it again. Add the fact that the navigation onscreen is hobbled by using a remote, and the frustration of using it simply isn't worthy the hassle.My computer is slightly old, and so is my TV, so maybe if you have only hardware purchased within the past year or so and are running only Google products it will work just fine. If you don't have the latest and greatest, this device will simply make you hate Google.
