review_text: I previously had an Amazon Firestick that constantly crashed and would spontaneously decide to reboot in the middle of me watching things, so I wanted to replace with something else and got the chromecast. At first I was a little concerned about not having a dedicated remote (you have to use your phone or another device to control it), but it has actually been really nice being able to (relatively) seamlessly switch between streaming across different devices -- if I am watching a video on my phone, I can just throw it on my tv via chromecast as opposed to making watching TV a separate/dedicated action. I also like that the flexibility of casting from my phone lets me stream things from almost any source, not just things with apps. My main complaint would be there are still a lot of steaming services (i.e. HBO) that do not have voice control yet (although I believe many are in the works), so you have to use your phone to control and cannot start a new episode just through voice control.

review_title: Works great on 2.4 G networks - 5G not so much
review_text: I recently changed my wifi provider and now have two wifi networks to choose from, the regular 2.4 G network and then the faster 5G network. It seemed to make sense to connect the chromecast to the faster 5G network, but that turned out to be a very bad idea. The chromecast constantly lost its network connection and froze, so I had to unplug and replug it to get things going again. Very annoying! After a bit of googling I found more 5G streaming device testaments of woe. So I connected my chromecast and phone to the 2.4 G network and haven't had a single problem since. 2.4 G is plenty fast for streaming movies, and I haven't noticed any problems in using my phone on the slower network either.

review_text: I now lead a remote free life because of this little guy. I control everything from my phone. I find it more convenient than a smart TV because you don't have to deal with inferior UI designed for TV or downloading or updating apps on the TV. Any app on my phone plays right to my TV. My TV is only 1080p so this thing does that perfectly and always looks perfect. I run the optical out from my TV to my stereo and control the volume with my phone too. No remotes needed, ever. Super convenient. Another plus is if a friend is over who has streaming services I don't they can still stream straight to my TV (as long as they have the app on their phone and they're on my Wifi).

author: Ian T. Roberts

review_title: Overall good, but NO RESET BUTTON
review_text: Overall, I love this product. It works like a charm out of the box. An unexpected pro: I can cast from my PC, and I cast things I wouldn't have expected I could cast, e.g., Spotify. Nice feature if, like me, you don't have good PC speakers.So, why the four stars? Because it lacks a reset button. Why do you need a reset button? Because when the internet goes out and then comes back, sometimes there no way to get the Chromecast to connect back to the network other than resetting the device, which requires plugging and unplugging the device. Really stupid way of doing things, and really awkward if your TV's ports are located in the back.Something else to consider: I like to watch TV while I eat, which sometimes make me wish I had a physical remote instead of having to use my phone to control the TV--easier to clean a remote than a smartphone screen, so you really don't want to get grease on your smartphone's screen.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2020
author: Arturo Javier

review_text: There are no insteructional videos for IPhone users. We spent over 4 hours trying to get our laptop connected to Chromecast. Laptop saw ouir Vizio tv, but no matter what we tried, we could not connect laptop to tv. Not as advertised. Bluetooth is an easy connect for our headphones, not so with a laptop. We are saying that you might get lucky, or might not. Do your due diligence and research the Google dongle and what it is caompatible with. Hope this helps. BTW, the instruction paper lists 3 steps to connect. Really? When you must download Google Home to you Iphone?, then play ring around the rosy? Not for us; we like "simple".

review_title: Works great while connected to the Internet
review_text: This product works great. There are times where it seems to struggle getting connected with the phone or laptop. The only disappointment is that this product requires a live Internet connection at all times. There is no option to even turn on without an active/live connection to the Internet. This means you cannot use this while camping, traveling, places with poor/limited network access. This was a deal breaker for us as we intended to use this in our RV for the kids while traveling. We decided to return this product and, instead, purchase a Miracast device. Otherwise, this is a great product with really good streaming abilities. If you intend to use this in a place with an active and continuous Internet connection, this is likely a great fit for your needs.

author: Soraya

review_title: Works poorly with a weaker Wi-Fi signal
review_text: With a strong Wi-Fi signal, it works pretty well, and I have few issues with it. But with a medium-strength signal (2 to 3 bars out of 3 on my phone), it works extremely poorly. The Chromecast and the phone constantly get out of sync (e.g. one is paused but the other thinks it's playing), but neither side realizes it. Often this can only be fixed by restarting the casting app, or even unplugging the Chromecast. The way I ended up fixing it was by buying a new Wi-Fi access point to put in the same room as it, because a couple rooms over wasn't good enough. This is with the YouTube app by the way, which is part of Google.Google really needs to do better QA in non-perfect network conditions. The Wi-Fi was plenty good enough to stream the actual videos in full HD; why is it not good enough to send commands properly?

The only solution is to have your finger ready to adjust the volume as soon as it kicks in - not a "good" solution. 2 - If you close down the app on your device while watching you lose the ability to control the streaming content because when you launch the app again it doesn't recognize the content streaming. The only solution I have found for this is to find the item we are watching again - and relaunch it. This is just annoying. It doesn't happen every time... but most of the time.

review_text: In my opinion, Chromecasts are king because they follow the KISS principle. I don't want a device that provides smartTV features that I don't even use and am not interested in. I want something that does it's one function and never complains and rarely breaks. I don't want to deal with another remote or the hassle of navigating menus. My phone is my remote. Period. When I want to watch something, most apps support the Chromecast natively and if they don't, I simply mirror my screen. No menus, no interfaces, nothing new to learn. I simply load up my app and cast it. BUH BAM, simple and effective!!

First, the original app is not available, now you have to use this garbage google home that looks and runs like somebody's HS intro to programming class project. It attempted to take over everything in my house from my Roomba, to my Sonos sound system. The only thing it couldn't find was my chromecast! After much screwing around, and setting up a dedicated, unsecured, router.......connecting the phone and the chromecast to the same router.......it sort of worked. I could cast some things, but almost nothing worked like the original one I had years ago. When it did work, the interface and controls were horribly slow. I mostly blame the google home app, which is completely ridiculous, a giant security issue, and incredibly buggy. I also suspect this is the main reason 3 years ago this was a 5 start item, and now it's dropping steadily. Returned and purchased another Roku.....a far far better device.

author: AlanAndMel

review_text: I love the idea of the Chromecast and was a big fan of the 1st Gen, but I’ve been having constant problems with the 3rd Gen.When it works it’s great: clean design, good quality video, & little buffering. However, after being on for a while it will inevitably randomly disconnect from your device before the video freezes a few seconds later. While it is frozen a loading/buffering animation will play in the center of the screen but it will never fix itself no mater how long you leave it. The only solution is a restart by unplugging it (as the reset button won’t work).At first I thought I received a defective product so I returned it and requested a new one. However, the new one also has the same issue (if not as common as the first device).Looking online for help I was told I had a bad WiFi connection, but the device is 3’ away from my WiFi router. I was told maybe the TV was interfering with the WiFi so I attached it to an extender cable to get it away from the TV. No dice.Maybe dropping $70 on a wired Chromecast might fix it, but I’m not sure I want to drop so much on a device that’s giving me so much trouble and I honestly doubt it’s really the WiFi.I’ve gone back to a 1st gen Chromecast for the time being. Despite it’s low picture quality and buffering at least it doesn’t require me to reset it nightly. :(

But it turns out the chrome cast is just as bad.When it works, I love it. The picture quality is good and the device is definitely convenient. The problem is, it’s super buggy. Once a day I have to unplug it and plug it back in because it decides that it’s no longer available to be connected to. Sometimes I come home and turn the tv on and it prompts me to hard reset it due to some sort of issue. Sometimes I’m in the middle of watching a show and it freezes. Sometimes it decides that it doesn’t want to use my phone as a remote control and goes rouge, to which I have to unplug it and plug it back in. It’s VERY frustrating and I’m about to send it back because I’m so unhappy. I’m gunna see how it goes for another week, but in the month+ I’ve had it, I'm not impressed....

review_text: very good goods

author: jajayjun

review_text: I purchased it in March specifically for the expected increase in home time due to the pandemic, so it's less than a year old and it causes me constant problems. It keeps disconnecting from apps, needs to be hard reset at least once a month and sometimes even that doesn't work the first time. When it does work, half the time the stream is blurry or out of sync between the visual and the sound. I don't have these issues when I'm watching directly on my phone or laptop and I've checked my wifi speed recently - 400+mbps - so that's not it.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2020
author: K. Hartman

review_text: This is a poorly designed product with awful endurance. It is fundamentally a device that is only useful for displaying various error messages related to connectivity issues in spite of range from wi-fi router and inabilities to stream applications for unspecified reasons. I may venture to even say that error messages have been displayed for longer durations than any movie or video I have, on anomalous occasions, been able to actually stream on this device. It is $30, however, so this is certainly a poster child for the saying "you get what you pay for". If I were to do it over again, I would go for something that is more functional, even if it is more expensive. This is an error-prone headache.
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 11, 2022
author: Jay

review_title: Extreme latency, unsuitable for most applications
review_text: Headline says it all. All I wanted was to stream my desktop display to the TV but MASSIVE latency (I'm talking over 1000 ms) makes this thing an expensive paperweight. I have gigabit internet and frequently game while streaming with a download in the background and have no problem, so I know my connection is good. Even with no programs open with no other drains on the bandwidth, however, it still has a massive latency. My phone casts to the same tv with no issues. Router and connection are absolutely not the problem. I don't know if this is a planned obsolescence thing or what because Steam and Razer both have functional products that do the same thing but this device is absolutely worthless. Knowing what I know now I wouldn't take this if it were free.
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2021
author: Shawn

review_title: What did we do without this before now??
review_text: We do NOT have cable, & don't pay for any TV/streaming/cable services. With this Chromcast, we can stream all sorts of shows, music, and just about anything on-line. It's been great! Can be used with most TVs, even ours that's 6-8 yrs old. Has saved us TONs of $$ & our teens are happy. We have 2 of these devices, & are considering purchasing another one for an old TV that we're going to put on Arizona Patio for outdoor use. Prior one is 2 yrs old & still going strong. Can be a bit finicky at times, but still not sure if that's operator error, our unreliable internet provider COX, or this device. Still WELL WORTH $$ & gives us many choices.
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 20, 2020

Not because of any defect, but because it's a significant change in the way we've interacted with TV for the last 50 years, particularly for us aging "boomer" types. I'd choose (and quickly switched to) the Roku.

I can screen mirror my tablet so I dont have to use my phone for TV and it be out of commission. Its connects very fast when you want to chromecast Hulu or Netflix and the picture is nice. review_title: Works better than my Smart TV

This year though, all these apps (Netflix, Prime Video, Hulu) have reallyyyy slowed down (or perhaps the rest of the world just sped up). I bought the chromecast and it has changed everything. Seriously, it works flawlessly and you use your phone/computer (whatever device you're casting from). Once I set up the chromecast with one device, the chromecast was visible to all other devices seamlessly. Just make sure your device and the chromecast are connected to the same wifi network. I think the newest version made things more complicated. Like it's trying to compete with FireStick or something? This version is perfect.

Chromecast Ultra is way too expensive just to add 4k/HDR support.All the above said, I went with a Chromecast over a competing product because of the Google Assistant integration and because of the ability to cast from a chromebook or my phone. So, I can control music playback easily using voice or the phone, and I can put up spreadsheets/presentations wireless on the TV. author: 19kilo

review_text: I bought a Chromecast 3rd generation because I have two other ultras that I own and want a backup. I ordered this unit on June 1, 2020. Last month, I replaced my router with a Netgear mesh router and two satellites. The two ultra Chromecast work fine; however, this 3rd generation does not appear in my list of devices. The software goes through all the motions, but at the end of the setup process, a message appears the unit has successfully loaded but may not show up in the devices' list. I have tried everything from restarting my router to resetting the Chromecast to factory settings to no avail. I reached out to tech support, but no one seems to support my need. I do not recommend this product if you are in the market for a simple casting device. Especially since Google isn't offering any resolution to my issue. I do not typically complain about a product, but in this case, I am not a happy customer.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2020
author: Robert S.

review_text: Garbage after the third use. Every time I tried using it I would have to reset it over and over until it would let me cast from my phone. It would register on my network and I could cast "live tv" but for whatever reason casting from my phone just was too much, even though thats, I don't know, its main purpose. I even factory reset it, did all the troubleshooting i could find on google(which was almost always reset it, reset your phone, reset your router, factory reset) I'd rather go back to using physical media than ever use this thing again. Waste of money, waste of time.

But I will keep it because my other Chromecast is so old and my other TV does have internet. There is no remote control So don't know why that question is asked.

No need to buy pay for TV services.

I also tried to bring it to someone else's house (I was house sitting), and it was only telling me that I was not connected to wifi, however it was not giving me the option to set it up on a new network which was very frustrating. However I must admit the remote on my phone is nice. If I were to be casting Netflix and exit the app it would continue playing, and if I wanted to control it from the google home app, I could.

review_title: just the ticket to bring big brother into your living room
review_text: so we have roku and a dvd player and media players etc I am a collector of technology or something so I figured why not it was only like 30 big ones. The marketers did their number on me I guess. It does work well and as advertised. The thing is since I already have roku and mostly watch high definition youtube videos, I am not using this one that much. Amazingly, it does not even have a great youtube app like roku even though both companies are owned by the same alphabet agency or something like that. This is mainly a screencaster. Dial something up on your tablet or phone and cast it to your TV it does that very well. The thing for me is I can already do that with my roku. It does have a nice screensaver. Problem it stays hot as hades all the time even when u arent using it I suppose its just collecting intelligence for the alphabet mothership all the time or something who knows. I have it turned off at the moment out of concern for the 5g radiation behind my head while I'm sleeping all nite. So it's ok. I like the Roku much better though and am still using that almost all the time.

It comes with a power cord that can either be plugged into an outlet or a USB on your tv. I prefer the outlet because if I start casting, it'll turn my tv on for me.

review_title: Setup a bit wonky but functionality great
review_text: I never thought I would need to purchase a Chromecast because I have been very happy with my Fire Stick. Unfortunately Hulu Live TV recently developed a software issue with Fire Sticks and Rokus where the video freezes up and remains that way until the software resets. (Hulu is aware of the issue.) So, I looked for a streaming hardware alternative since I like the channels and format offered by Hulu Live. The Chromecast was the least costly alternative to the Fire Stick. I'm glad I discovered this alternative. The setup was a bit wonky and didn't work the first time. The Chromecast couldn't read my TV correctly. I have a smart TV that became dumb when it could no longer read my wifi, so I need that interface that a Fire Stick or Chromecast provides. So, I reset the Chromecast and reinstalled the Chromecast. It worked this time. While I like the onboard functionality and menus that Fire provides and Chromecast does not, the Chromecast will do its job for me. The Chromecast also is controlled by an Android or iOS phone. This is pretty slick and makes it easy to control the functions of not only the Chromecast, but Hulu and my TV as well. I will still use my Fire Stick with most of my other paid streaming services, but I'll use the Chromecast for Hulu Live TV. This has (hopefully) put the video freezing issue in my rearview mirror.I gave it 4 out of 5 stars because of the issues with the setup.

author: Angela thao

review_title: Why is this still a product?
review_text: So here is what I did a while ago... I bought a Hiearcool USB C Hub for my Samsung s4 tablet because I have an older TV I can't cast to. I plugged my tablet into the hub, the hub into my TV via HMDI, and it worked perfectly. Just hit the cast button on the tablet, choose the TV, and you are done. The only problems being that while plugged in, you can't turn the tablet screen off. And of course, you have to keep your tablet cabled. So I figured I would get one of those Chromecast things, and eliminate the cable. Go full-wifi. Well, that was a bad idea.From the beginning, I didn't like the device because as I learned, you need Google Home on Android to cast to it, which I had already uninstalled from my tablet because it was obviously just a way for Google to attempt to steal more of my information. My hub just worked right out of the box. But I reinstalled it and gave it a shot. Unlike the hub, there was a setup and update process. The hub I just plugged in and it worked fine. I still had to use the hub because this Chromecast has no option for connecting my wireless usb mouse. The first serious issue I noticed is that the screen kept going back to the setting of fit width instead of fit height, thereby cutting off the android screen options top and bottom (notifications and home screen icons). Then while testing out some Netflix using the app, I was getting sound, but no picture. Googling for help didn't provide much of it. Just a lot of confusing posts about people guessing at what the cause of the problem was.The wifi connection was fine, though honestly, the wifi router, Chromecast, and tablet are all within a few feet of each other, so it is what you would expect. But I tried it out elsewhere, and even casting down stairs to the living room produced a very nice, clear picture. Except for Netflix video for some reason. I figured I would solve the problem eventually, and went on to test out the device. Other video channels seem to be fine. But there were still other negatives.It seems you need to always keep the Chromecast powered - plug or TV usb. The USB C hub is powered by the tablet, with a pass-through that allows you to charge the tablet without having to remove the hub. And the hub is always just a little warm to the touch even after hours of use. The Chromecast is very hot to the touch after just a few minutes. And after leaving for a while and coming back, the Chromecast didn't connect automatically to the tablet. I had to do a restart the tablet. Only happened once, so it may have been a fluke.So with the hub being $10 less, its own real disadvantage was the cable from the tablet to the hub. But compared to the Chromecast, that seemed like a non-issue at the end of the day. So with there being a cheaper and more seamless option that requires practically no setup or updates, works consistently well, and doesn't need Google Home, why is Chromecast still a thing?I will keep the Chromecast for when I travel or visit friends so I can keep my tablet in my hands, but quite honestly, it is going to get very little use at home.*The one thing I should note about the Hiearcool USB C Hub and other hubs like it is that it only works with devices that allow for a HDMI direct connection. Not all tablets do, so you have to check your tablet specs first to see if it is capable. Otherwise, casting through wifi is your only option.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2020

review_title: Compared to Apple TV, I like this more
review_text: I am a Apple fan and have all apple products. I don't want to make it as war review between Apple and other companies, but wanted to give a context so people know where i am coming from.I have Apple TV for more than 3/4 years now. Very happy with the functionality etc till recently i have a need of one more steaming device. Visiting a friend and they had Chromecast. They asked me to try. Amazon is best place to get it since if you don't like, no questions asked while returning it. Any ways, Got it, setup was a breeze, out of the box it was all set and running like a pro.Now, I am sometime forgetting i have Apple TV. Switching it on, searching the app, typing what you are looking is now a pain. Instead with Chromecast, i search on my phone, one button and it goes to my TV. Phone becomes my remote, so much simple, i have purchase two more for other bedrooms :)
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2019

review_title: If you want to stream your Android tablet on a not smart tv this is excellent
review_text: Using this on a Samsung screen 4 years old and not smart. This is excellent for this 1080p bedroom tv. Use it mainly to stream NBC peacock the picture is excellent. Thanks to Google for an excellent easy to use product. The usb connection on tv powers the Chromecast unit when tv is off Chromecast is off perfect.

Not sure what other omissions there are, but this is enough to really frustrate me.

author: Amazon Customer

review_title: Google Chromecast can make any screen a smart TV
review_text: The Google Chromecast is an absolute must-have in any household that has a Google Home Speaker already installed. If you don't have a Google speaker already in your household then any Android phone works just as well with the Chromecast. This little device has the ability to make any TV or projector TV into a smart TV. There's tons of entertainment and steaming applications that can be used on this device. The applications do have to be downloaded on your device and can't be saved directly to the Chromecast device. Chromecast gives you the ability to make your phone control what your watching or listening to. When used along with the Google Home Speaker settings can be enabled which has the ability to entirely control the TV and which applications you are viewing on the screen completely with only your voice and the correct commands.
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2019

I've had a few Chromecast and the 3rd gen is beyond the best gen. Currently, I have one built into my Vizio 4k tv. date: Reviewed in the United States on May 11, 2021
author: Tim

review_title: DON'T BUY IF YOU WANT TO CAST PHONE SCREEN WITH UNLIMITED DATA PLAN
review_text: One star is only for product marketing being so misleading:If you want to use the "unlimited" (a misnomer!) high speed data from your cell phone, to steam video and cast same onto a big screen TV--- without using hotspot data or a separate internet service provider---THIS WILL NOT WORK! :(I know it suggests different in the descriptions here, as it does with fire stick and roku---and as do a myriad of seemingly helpful (and sometimes savvy) users....BUT FORGET THEM ALL. They are all wrong!Seriously. ;/You MUST have either mobile hotspot data OR a separate internet service connection. Period.You CAN NOT use your phone's unlimited data plan to cast a phone screen which is streaming content (amazon prime video, netflix, whatever), onto a large area device. It simply does not work. Lots of technical reasons for that, but I will spare you the Gory Geek Greek, (you came here for a product workaround, not an engineering degree-right?).I am an engineer, I solve problems like this for a living.I have done the research.I have spent months trying to find a work around.There just isn't one.Save yourself the frustration, and all this junk they are trying to sell us for this particular application.You can not use unlimited cell phone mobile data to stream video direct from phone to roku/firestick/chromecast devices, (or similarly enabled Smart TV's).Watch video on your phone, or go back to the ole' DVD/DVD Player routine.You can NOT cast a streaming service of high quality video content onto a big screen TV without hotspot data or other internet service. Just can not. There, I said it 4+ times. :)
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2020
author: Alberto Knox

review_text: This is a productive creation I use very often at home in my bedroom, and it does not have lag nor glitches (unless of course your internet is malfunctioning or being hacked) and is even more smooth with the output than my Roku TV applications and I love it. review_text: Tbh I bought this as a response to my previous phone having issues with dead pixels. Set up was a little shaky, but once I got it going, it was really easy to use! After that, it was smooth sailing and and I now just use it as a my monitor for my mobile games when I can!I'm gushing, but the main point I'm making is if you find yourself with a dead-pixelling screen and need to see what's going on, once your figure out how to navigate it, this will be a life [and by consequence, data] saver!

review_title: Great Value and we have bought several of these!
review_text: Great value! And as expected for the price. We seem to need to replace ours about once a year. Set up is a little confusing, however once it is set up the Chromecast is very simple and easy to use, which is why i keep buying these over and over. The streaming is spotty at times and doesn’t always show as available. We have to reset it every couple days. KEEP IN MIND Some of these issues may be related to my raul internet service. I’m not really tech savvy enough to know for sure. You can turn on the TV and control the TV volume to an extent. Sometimes it’s way to quite and other times it’s way too loud. Clearly none of these issues have been frequent enough or intolerable to the point that replaced it with something “better”. I actually had a fire stick and gave it to my dad after trying the Chromecast for my bedroom TV. I have found that other “wifi broadcasting devices” all have their own pros and cons too!

author: Luke Orion

review_title: Exceedingly convenient but a few minor setbacks
review_text: Compared to other devices for streaming, this is the best out there in my mind, having tried the Firestick, Chromecast, and Roku. Here is my list of pros and cons:Pro:You don't need a remote to work this - it's accessible from your phone. You also don't need to log into your accounts on the device, since it just Chromecasts right to your TV, and you can modify the volume, what's playing, etc from there.You don't need to change HDMI outlets manually - it will switch automatically if you put something up to stream.You can chromecast a tab on your computer, or the entire screen, just as easily as your phone.Setup is ridiculously easyPrice is low and no monthly/recurring costIt's easy for other people to hop on and use at the same time, since they just need their phoneThe screensavers that it flashes between when not playing anything are beautiful!Cons:This actually needs to be plugged into an outlet along with the TV. Once it's there, you forget about it, but this felt clunky.Streaming from a computer screen can be a bit laggy, but I've yet to find a better solution.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2021

I then suspected if Googlechromecast 3 could have anything to do with it.. however, I debunk the idea..Few months later, I had recommended my friends to buy chromecast gen3 to resolve their need to watch GolfTV app onto a TV.. one of the had bought the device, and reported similar problem after its use to His HOme theatre system.. hence, I would advise anyone not to buy, unless this issue is resolved or the company share knowledge article to fix the issue

It would be nice if the new Chromecast with Google TV had an audio breakout jack(s) that provided good quality higher res audio support if Google is not going to re-release the Chromecast Audio. So there you go, the need for a second device requiring power to get Chromecast audio connected to a standalone amplifier.

author: Marnatee

review_text: LAST UPDATE 2-25-2021 - Frustrated near the point of insanity, I gave up, returned it. Amazon was great trying to help. I could NOT get the dongle to stop disconnecting. If there is something I did not try over 2 months, I don't know what I missed. I finally used software to tell me what everything in my network was doing. The problem was never my phone, never my router, never band width, I finally caught the dongle disconnecting and got confirmation. I ordered an MHL ($18) and hardwired my needs with USBC from my phone to HDMI plugged into my monitor. Time to open package and download app 1.5 minutes. Total set up time 22 seconds. End result ... PERFECT. All I ever wanted was to monitor an outdoor security camera. I have my tablet sitting next to my monitor 10 feet away from me so no cable is running across the floor. Everything is hidden behind the monitor. I use my phone, which is also WIFI connected to the outdoor camera as is my tablet is, to manipulate the camera. It all works flawlessly, and the picture on the monitor is radically great (HDMI quality). Oh what a relief it is!UPDATE 2-8-2021: Final chapter, problem solved but I don't like it:Disconnects continued. Tired of messing with this I set up the MOST IDEAL SETUP and tested to see if I could make this dongle work under the most optimum conditions possible. I moved my router, my phone, and this dongle attached to the monitor I was casting to, to TOUCHING distance apart. Literally in a neat pile touching each other. The disconnects finally stopped. I bought a 10 foot HDMI cord (not happy I had to), and relocated my router to a new but equally as powerful location as the former. I ran the HDMI cable from the monitor connection to my router, and DUCT TAPED this dayme dongle to the side of it!!!!! No more disconnects. Folks, I have EIGHTEEN WIFI devices, indoor and out, some 6 times as far from my router as this dongle was, and not a single one has ever spontaneously disconnected. If you say you never had this problem, I believe you, but I can conclude nothing other than MY dongles were lame. Didn't expect this from a Google product.UPDATE: 2-3-2021: I read a comment on another forum that if you just can't figure out the disconnects, it just might be the dongle itself is defective (duh... why didn't I go there?). I asked Amazon to send me a replacement so I could test that. They had one on my door step 10 hours later (Amazon is so great in so many ways). I installed the new dongle. It has been connected for 6 consecutive hours (last thing last evening the old one was disconnecting every few minutes). If this dongle goes a few weeks without going insane, I'll let you all know.I am giving this one star in all aspects because it is just such a hassle. It works fine for a short time (few days-couple of weeks) then with NO CHANGES made to my network... and I mean NONE...ZERO, this dongle goes into a fit of disconnects, over and over, every few minutes. Google says there are MANY fixes. The one I found that works is to RESET and set up with the Home app AGAIN. That does stop the problem.... for a few days-couple of weeks again. I never have to make any adjustments to any other part of my network. If I had known this was going to need so much dam babysitting I would have never bought it. I have many wireless devices: cameras, smart lights, Nest minis, monitors, head phones, RGBIC strips... blah blah... NOTHING ELSE behaves badly, just this Chromecast DONGLE. NOT-WORTH-IT.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2021

author: Amazon Customer

review_title: not as flexible as I was expecting
review_text: I've got a projector with only one HDMI input, but I have a couple of devices that connect to it through a splitter, which has been working fine for a couple of years. All but two of the devices can be configured to output in either RGB or ycbcr. This apparently only outputs in ycbcr, while my more frequently used PS4 only outputs in RGB. Hence, it's a minor hassle to go into the projector settings and change the input mode when I want to use the chromecast and then change it back when I'm done.Like plenty other of these app-driven devices, it can also be slow and inconsistent for the Home app to connect and respond. It's similar to driving an Apple TV from the remote app, which is typically only something I resort to when a kid has hidden the physical remote somewhere. Plus, casting isn't as universally available as I was expecting. Most apps it works in, but some have it intentionally disabled, apparently.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2019

review_title: Works great, love it, but it can and does overheat
review_text: Turns my older but still trusty TV into a multimedia center. Works great with YouTube, Netflix, Hulu, and yes, Amazon Prime Video. Setup is a little quirky.Why three stars for a pretty cool little product? This device has a fairly major flaw - it overheats. In fact, it gets so hot, it will shut off after a few minutes of streaming HD video. I read about other users modding theirs to add heat sinks, but I just set up a desktop fan behind my TV and aimed it at it and that works great.Still though, definitely not ideal. Future models may have solved this problem, so I am only speaking specifically about the 3rd Generation Chromecast.Do you have a TV in your bedroom that's a few years old, but you still wanna Netflix and Chill? Buy this little device, its awesome! But be advised you may need a fan. There are alternatives of course, but the price of this little gadget is hard to beat.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2020

review_text: I had the first-gen Chromecast, and it sat unconnected for years, since it was essentially unusable. Google's gotten its act together with the third gen of this product. There are still glitches -- my phone occasionally disconnects from the Chromecast, and screen mirroring from the phone is awful -- but otherwise this is a big improvement. Services that play directly through the Chromecast -- Netflix, HBO Max, YouTube, etc. -- play smoothly and reliably, and mirroring from my desktop PC, including full-screen video, is quite good. For the price, this is a great way to get streaming services onto your TV.

review_title: Google Chromecast (3rd Generation) Really Nice & Affordable.
review_text: This Google Chromecast really was simple to install, is well made and works quite well with most programs that have cast capabilities. The picture quality is excellent and the Ease of use couldn't be simpler. My only complaint would be if Google and Amazon could resolve their issues with each other and work together. The only kink in using this casting device is with Amazon-Prime video use. You can use it but not with an Apple phone as your remote. You have to "start/stop/pause" from your Amazon program on the computer. One company or the other does not allow this to work with an Apple iPhone (hence the 4-star rating). Other than that, this is well worth the bang for the buck.

I disconnected the chrome cast from my google home and tried to reconnect it but the device was not detectable and could not be found no matter what I did. review_text: Chromecast is the greatest streaming device I've used so far. In the past, I have used AppleTV, the Amazon Firestick, and the Amazon Fire TV. For it's price, lack of taken-up space, easy usability, and minimalistic approach to watching TV, Chromecast is worthy of purchase.

author: Shabnam Hassan

review_title: You CAN'T use this without some WAN internet connection somewhere
review_text: Maybe some of you are looking at this because you share my goal: to play video files you own to an HDMI screen without any internet connection. "No internet" means a local wifi network is okay, but no data from "outside", even over a cellphone connection. I mean like if you're in a remote cabin in the woods, or if you're in a hotel in a foreign country where you have no cell service and no internet connection at all. This *should* be a simple goal: data on a hard drive, transmitted over a wireless connection to a Chromecast (or Roku or ...), to watch on a screen.A few places on the internet seemed to suggest that as long as you have a local connection (LAN, not WAN), the newer Chromecasts would allow you to play video files over that LAN. But this is simply false, as I can attest simply by experimentation, and as a Google product support specialist later confirmed for me. I could stream files from my Western Digital Wireless Pro (basically a hard drive with travel router attached) to the Chromecast *only* while the WDWP was itself connected to the internet. Same story with various other configurations I tried, including a RAV Travel router - everything works fine until the moment the LAN is no longer connected to the internet, and then it mysteriously stops working, even though all the data it needs is all local.The Roku stick won't let you do it either, by the way. This is maddening, in my book. The only ways I found to get content onto an HDMI TV from a video file basically involve either a large flash drive plugged into the TV's usb port (always clumsily handled by the TV, in my experience), or a *wired* connection like a cave person (for example, from my iPad via a lightning-to-HDMI dongle and a *long* HDMI cable), or else using a Raspberry Pi. Stupid, but there it is.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2020

review_title: Misleading information, does not work as advertised
review_text: I assume a vast majority of people buy these to use Netflix, Hulu, and other streaming type apps on their TV instead of watching on their phones. The description says "stream directly from your phone" but this is NOT what it does. All it does is stream from the internet and your phone becomes a remote control. Completely useless.If you're watching videos downloaded onto your phone then it will work fine. Note that I DO NOT mean videos downloaded from Netflix or Hulu to be played offline. Trying to cast these to the Chromecast will just make it start streaming from the internet - it does NOT play the offline video downloaded on your phone. Totally useless for those that have poor internet connections (or none at all) and want to watch legitimate downloaded Netflix/Hulu/Prime movies and shows on a larger screen.
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2020

review_title: Does not have screen mirroring for iOS devices....
review_text: I bought this unit specifically to mirror screen my iPhone to my 2015 smart Samsung TV. Some reviewers said it would do it and others said it would not. So I gave it a try. I installed it to my TV, downloaded and installed the required app, but it didn't work. iPhone and TV both have mirror screening options available, both were using the WiFi signal, both devices showed to be connected to the internet wifi and ready to be connected, but neither device could find the other. After a lot of research about this unit, I finally found the one sentence I was looking for: The unit will not mirror screen with iso devices. BINGO!!This unit may be perfect for all the things it's advertised to do, but according to their own troubleshooting information, it cannot "mirror screening" or air play "mirror screening" with iso devices, regarding of what other reviewers may say. I would encourage the Seller to clearly state this in the product details.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2021

review_text: This product is great to run from an iPhone. However, it won't run from my HP chromebook. I spent about 2 hours online trying to fix the problem, followed by 50 minutes of tech support from chromecast, and I only have audio but no video when casting from the chromebook. If you are a teacher or presenter and want to utilize this product when presenting, you will be disappointed, unless you present from your iPhone. I would have given 5 stars if i only tried it on my iPhone, but the fact that it is easier to run from iPhone than from a chrome operating system on a chromebook shows that it has fundamental flaws. And to those that suggest it is just "operator error", it operates fine from my iPhone after I set it up. The chromecast tech support could not fix the issue either.

review_text: Not really a review as I barely used it. I'm sure it is a good enough streaming device but that was not what I was expecting. I did read the puck needs Internet for setup and sure enough it immediately updated its firmware when connected. But I expected once configured and connected to my phone, it would mirror the content on my phone, using my phone's data like a Bluetooth speaker. Turns out it can only stream content via WiFi. I should have known since there are no Bluetooth or NFC options for connecting to your phone.Google calls it a "cast" because the controlling device "casts" the link to the content for this puck to begin its it's own streaming. Your phone merely acts as a remote control. In other words, if you've cut the Internet cord, this puck does nothing but drain your hotspot bucket.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2019

author: Hannah Simpson

review_title: Great but it only works half of the time
review_text: I have my whole house in the Google/Nest ecosystem. I really wanted this to work. Troubleshooting my 2nd generation Chromecast I finally gave up, it was a nightmare. I bought this Gen 3 Chromecast in the hopes that it would fix my reliability issues. It has not but now I have introduced entirely new failure modes, so that's fun. I've had a sophisticated friend helping me and neither of us can get this to work reliably. My wifi is Google mesh and I'm casting from a Pixel 5. It's all Google so you would think it would work together. We've tried assigning static IP address etc, etc. All the things we can find on the forums. While casting with YouTube or Netflix it freezes periodically and will only play for 2-3 seconds with each push of the play button. Sometimes it returns to the YouTube TV home screen in the middle of a video. Sometimes it does even weirder stuff. I'm giving up on this and maybe on Google home entirely
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2021

author: Coast Girl

review_text: I bought this to stream thru my projectorThis thing is useless w 5.1 audio and many apps wont let you turn off the 5.1Endless audio sync problems w apps. Amazon Prime make sure turn off the Digital Dolby otherwise you will have audio out of sync. Works beautiful when its offOnly works w Disney Plus if you turn on the audio w description which forces it into stereo when you cast Disney it forces you into Dolby 5.1 which then causes audio sync issues. Every video I have tried on Disney is pushed into whatever 5.1 they have and you have zero options to turn it off the only work around is audio w description the everything is fine but you have a narration that destroys any hope of enjoying anythingHulu if the show or movie doesn't have dolby 5.1 your fine... the older shows and movies Elementary Star Trek Angel etcTill I tried newer shows like Stumptown and Orville the audio is out of sync unless you turn on on audio w description which forces it into stereo. I cant explain thisZero problems w youtube I don't have NetflixThe bonus is you can stream Chrome browser stuff from a desktop or stream from VLC sometimes there's no rhyme or reason why one file plays fine and one will only play the audio.Another issue is Hulu and Disney plus get weird w the app the control is lacking and aggravating Amazon Prime is the opposite total ease of useSo I either have to invest into hdmi audio splitter to essentially downgrade the audio into 2 channel stereo since there isnt an option within chromecast or the ios app doesn't have this feature and hope that works or just buy a different stickReally irritated that this thing doesn't live up to the hypeRead up on all of the audio sync problems before you buy this personally I think its crap and doesn't deliver
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2020

review_text: These are the use-cases Chromecast won't solve:1. Remote Calls and meetings (Facebook Messenger, What's app, Zoom).- Video works great, but no sound (or sound coming out fo the phone, not TV)2. Ability to cast/mirror screen from any iPhone device (not supported)3. Ability to control sound output format (settings removed on latest release)If you happen to find yourself in the middle of a pandemic and need to take calls on your TV using any social media or meeting app (including meet.google.com), skip this product or get yourself an additional speaker because Chromecast cannot patch audio from these. Also, forget about mirroring from an iPhone.

review_title: Combine different video sources to a central TV
review_text: I recently purchased this 3rd generation cast and add it to my TV. I have an existing earlier version added to my other TV. However it took me about 1/2 hour to figure out how to add it under the control of my phone. While the instruction was written in orderly fashion that made it clear to follow, there are steps not clear enough to make the installation a smooth one. But once connected, the quality of the pictures are almost as good as original but small resolution are lost. Also there are different video players compatible with Chromcast such that with one click, the picture gets redirected to the TV. Overall, other than a little technical difficulties with the install, everything else work as expected.

author: Krissia Lizano

review_text: The quality of the streaming is good, but I quite often have difficulty casting to my TV with this device. I've had to reset the device multiple times when streaming Netflix since half the time it freezes up and my phone says it is unable to connect. When streaming Disney+, it'll connect but the controls won't work from the phone. It is as if it sent the signal to start casting but after it starts, it losses connection with the streaming device. I've tried resetting both the device and my phone multiple times and it is plugged in to the wall for power through the USB adapter, but I still continue to have these issues. I've only streamed from a laptop top about two times but didn't seem to have any problems this way, so just know, if you tried to stream from a mobile device, you may have trouble. If you can get it to work consistently, it's a great device with great streaming quality, but sadly while the issue continue I can only give it three stars.
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2021

review_text: No support m…I gave up as it was constantly going wonky and did not have settings menus to fix anything!. Even Apple spent more time trying to help me try to get Apple TV+ app to stream, when Google’s help site was just well, screwing with me. They know they aren’t supporting users. They think “let’s get the community to do the work” but the product controls are so vapid it is impossible to “commune” on its use. To me, it is arrogant to put a product out to consumers that lacks any kind of menu, reasonable help files, nor reliable setup approaches. It wastes people’s time. A bunch of developers with big heads that confuse their desire to be technically elite with the reality that they are not delivering an elite experience. They are delivering white noise. Like a blank canvas parading as modern art. The Emporer’s New Clothes. No menu. No help. A lot of nothing posing as something. I returned it and got a Roku 4K for 29.00 at Staples and what a difference. It practically set itself up. It worked. Also supports Apple TV+ which Chromecast does not. And there is no need to stream from another device. Roku makes your TV into a smart tv, has a remote that sync so you can operate the tv or stream, and it knows to switch inputs on its own without being told. You no longer need your phone to stream. You get a huge menu of apps. It is far superior. Makes Chromecast look like a hack.
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 8, 2022

The box shows lots of streaming apps and gives the impression that they're included. Nope. Apparently all the chromecast does is let you cast from your phone to your tv. That's it, and that won't work for me. I have elderly relatives and also a child who visit my home regularly and also like to watch Netflix, and need to be able to do so without a smartphone. I'm planning to return the chromecast and get a fire stick instead.

review_title: Frustrating until it feels like cooperating
review_text: I had an older version of this that you could plug into the TV, and the problem was it would always randomly disconnect while playing something- no excuse, not because of wifi or the tv/playstation itself, just because it was old. So I bought this updated version, and while I appreciate it for working differently than the other TV connection devices (roku, apple, etc) far as ease and not needing a remote, it still gives me problems where every time I turn my TV off after using it, I have to unplug to reset it when I want to turn it back on- instead of it just acting normal. It's a major inconvenience if EVERY time I want to use it, it pretends like it doesn't exist (on my laptop) until I go behind the TV and reconnect it, which should've only been a thing to do the very first time I installed. Had it for 2 months now and it honestly pisses me off every time. Would return and give in to the other ones, but return window is up.

review_title: does what it says it does, but there is no way to turn it off, making it useless for my monitor
review_text: The chromecast works as expected, but ended up being nearly completely useless for my use case.There is no way to turn the chromecast off. When its not streaming, it goes in "Ambient" mode, which means streaming a slideshow of pictures. THERE IS NO WAY TO DISABLE AMBIENT MODE. thats right, your chromecast, from the second you plug it in, will be using your bandwidth to stream a slideshow to your TV EVEN WHEN YOU'RE NOT LOOKING AT IT. Short of unplugging it after you're done watching it, it will be considered an "active" input on your TV/monitor.This is where my usecase fails. I have mine plugged into my monitor, and I want to stream content, then when i'm done I want my monitor to automatically go to sleep when it detects that my chromecast is now "inactive", just like it does when my laptop goes to sleep. However, since there is no way to disable ambient mode, the chromecast is active forever and I have to get up and turn off my monitor or unplug the chromecast when I want to go to bed.
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 11, 2020

review_text: Chromecast is simple to use. We occasionally purchase these as a gifts for friends and family. However, it can be buggy for months at a time. The most resent issue has made the device unusable for our most commonly used streaming service, YouTube.If connecting YouTube via Chromecast with an Android device, the connection will not last through the first video.*Solution: find an old iPhone/iPad and add your play list. For whatever reason that connection is more stable.**Presently the issue is significantly less pronounced when using steaming services other than YouTube.***This issue or others like it have been present since we purchased our first Chromecast seven years ago.****We are curious if a Kindle Fire is a better solution but will likely stick with what we have because my husband is not a fan of the bald oligarch who doesn't pay taxes. However, we bought the Chromecast on Amazon so, cheers Bezos, enjoy your yaught while your employees pee in bottles and die in Tornados.

I got online and it seems to be a huge issue for MANY other people as well. It makes this product virtually useless. There needs to be a firmware update or something to fix it. Was trying to Cast shows, and sound and video would glitch/hiccup with my old, 1st Generation Chromecast. Was running fine on Computer, but glitching on TV/Chromecast. review_text: Do NOT buy this garbage. I have purchased 2 Google home devices and 3 chromecast devices and four out of 5 of them have proven defective. Google should stick to software and search engines because their hardware products are absolute garbage. We had trouble connecting these devices to wifi initially and once they were connected more problems started. We returned the ones we could. Do yourself a favor and buy any other streaming TV device that isn't made by the Google brand. Get a tivo or roku. Anything but chromecast. Get a fire stick. We only bought it because it was supposed to support the spectrum tv app where roku and fire do not, but it has become a useless device in my house that does nothing. I have followed all the troubleshooting steps on the Google Chromecast help page and all of their suggestions have failed. All I have left to do is the frustration of calling their customer service number in hopes of resolution or trying to return this defective piece of garbage to Amazon. Hopefully one of these resolutions works.
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2021

review_title: it Cast one day but Not casting the next Day
review_text: I have a chronmecast (Probably, the 2nd generation) stopped working after 3 yrs., so I ordered this one, it arrived on 4/13/2020; I set it up, it worked fine for the 1st couple days, because I don't cast it everyday; Then recently since last week, it cast Youtube to my TV, but it doesn't cast the next day; I reset it to factory reset, it cast without a problem for one night , then it does not cast the next night when I clicked on the square box cast icon... i am very frustrating ...no support is available .. try to replace it with the same item, but there is no option to do so at Amazon.com; I probably will have to return it.

author: Macy Alfred

review_title: Fails EVERY use case outside the most basic
review_text: This device managed to overwhelmingly fail in more situations than it succeeded, an incredible feat I have never experienced in a mainstream brand:1. Stream Twitch: GLITCHY - Microstutters every 5-10 seconds2. Mirror PC desktop: LAGGY - 1-2 second delay makes mouse input borderline unusable3. Cast photos/videos from phone (using Google Photos on Google Pixel 2): FAIL - video sound did not work at all. photos take many seconds to "unpixelate"4. Mirror Oculus VR: OK. Connection is finnicky, but does work5. Wifi compatibility: FAIL - Tried at brother's house, failed to connect to wifi at all.I can only imagine what all the 5-star reviewers are doing with their Chromecasts -- maybe the most popular streaming apps like Netflix/HBO/etc are working correctly?Background: I have a strong tech background and these are all networks that have had zero problems with other devices and apps. We tried two different Chromecast devices, same results.Further rants: Google has aggressively pushed Google Cast to replace e.g. Samsung's support of Miracast in their Android phones, to the point of dropping Miracast entirely. The irony is that Miracast, despite its flaws, actually worked for many of the above use cases. This entire situation reflects very poorly on Google's attitudes towards its customers (a.k.a guinea pigs) and has been strong motivation to switch to iPhone/AirPlay

review_title: Long time user of Chromecasts. After my 5th, I won't buy another one
review_text: Chromecasts used to be awesome, but updates to the Chrome browser don't take functionality of the Chromecast, or the apps that support Chromecasts, into consideration, so with each Chrome update, most of the apps don't work anymore and the Chromecast barely functions until they push an update out. And as for the apps, most developers have given up trying to rewrite their apps to keep up with Chrome updates. And these are very finicky. Without an EXACT amount of power going to these, they start to act up. And they wear out quickly. I'm on a Roku now and so far it seems to be much more reliable.

review_title: Like resetting it daily! Google wifi devices are not maintenance free! Not for security cameras!
review_text: Google home and its products are a great toy, but that's about it! ALL THE NEW GOOGLE NEST WIFI PRODUCTS WILL LOSE NETWORK CONNECTIVITY AND REQUIRE REGULAR USER INTERVENTION TO MAINTIAN CONECTIVITY! I have over 30 years experience as a computer and electrical engineer and design microcontroller system. So I have some technical knowledge. My home is already automated by my own built systems, but I wanted to try out the Google Home and Nest products for family members. I CAN NOT RECOMEND IT! Google is going backwards with their new "Nest" technology. Instead of trying to making it simpler, they are making it utterly useless. It is still a couple years away from being a reliable and usable system. I wasted well over $1000 trying to give the Nest product line a decent review over the last month. I am disgustingly disappointed. All of the new Google wifi products have a reputation of bad network management and refuse to automatically reestablish a connection when lost. All of the Nest products require user intervention just to keep them connected and working. It's almost a daily chore now to figure out what devices dropped off the network and to get them reconnected. Older google products, BEFORE Nest, have not experienced any wifi failures. Such as the original google thermostat. I have it mounted in a detached garage over 50 feet away with the worst wifi signal and it has no problem staying connected, as long as it is NOT on the "Google Nest wifi" network. All the newer Google products, such as the Chromcast, Nest Learning Thermostat, Nest Wifi, Google Hub Max, Nest Hello, and the Nest Yale lock all have issues with network connectivity, with and without the Google Nest Wifi. I only experience network loss with the Nest product line. No other wifi device in my home experiences network connectivity issues, as long as it's not on the Nest Wifi. Even my Android phone tells me it is switching over to cell service because the Nest wifi can not reach the internet when I am 5 feet from the router, meanwhile my tablets on my Cisco or netgear routers stay connected. The Google Hub Max is 10 feet from the Google Nest Wifi router and drops connection at least once a day. The Max Hub is the only device that I have witnessed attempting a reconnection. All the other devices do not even show an attempt to reconnect in the router network logs. It's as if the Nest devices were powered down but they are all on, alive and still disconnected. I have a few chromecast's installed within 5 feet of a Nest wifi point which is 25 feet from the router and they all have a strong wifi signal and they still loose connection separately. The Chromcast and the Google Hub display CAN NOT reliably stream live security cameras! It keeps popping up with the on screen player controls, for a live stream that has no control, that blacks out the bottom half of the screen for up to 10 seconds making the video useless. Since both of the devices operate on Wifi if there is any packet loss you are stuck looking at the player controls indefinably, making the video completely useless. All the newer Nest products loose wifi connection at least once a week at random and individually, it's almost never any 2 devices on the same wifi point unless the wifi point itself failed. It is not the wifi network because I have tried 3 different wifi router systems on nearly every wifi channel with the same results. I even used 2 different RF spectrum analyzers to make sure I do not have any stray RF signals interrupting the wifi signals. If it says "Google Nest" on the product be ready for daily network maintenance!
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 1, 2021

review_title: Mirror your phone screen videos have a low frame rate.
review_text: Right out of the box. The setup was pretty easy. Plug in, download the app, and connect to it. First time casting to the screen was fine. After that is where things started to sour. The quality of my phones home screen on the TV was horrendous but I continued and started playing home videos. The more it played the worse the frame rate got after 15 minutes it was so bad it couldn't keep up with what my phones screen had on so I disconnected my phone from it. Looking at the help support it says my phone (Moto z4) wasn't on the optimized phones list for Casting but my old phone was (Moto z2 play) So I test it out and couldn't get it connect. After messing with it for 30 mins or so I finally got it to connect again but still had the same issues frame rate and picture quality are bad the longer you use it. Until it gets to a point where it freezes. It felt hot like it was overheating.
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2019

review_title: Needs internet. Even for screen cast.
review_text: Kind of stupid design. I primarily wanted it to screencast. I'm not paying for internet so I thought it would be fun to cast videos from my phone to my TV. However the way this thing is designed it needs internet. Basically it runs off of its own apps. So it's not really mirroring your device it's just using your device as credentials to log into that application on the Chromecast and display it on the tv. Meaning that if you don't have internet or router you can't even cash to your TV screen. Which is really stupid design because that's all I wanted.

review_text: Feels almost featureless. But that's not my main problem.Chromecast 3rd GenH.264 High Profile up to level 4.2 (1080p/60fps)VP8 (720p/60fps or 1080p/30fpsMost of the videos I watch come in H.265 codec, making this streaming device utterly useless. I didn't see this anywhere in the description. Or that this device is 3rd gen. If you aren't sure what codec you're streaming in or have a 4k tv (which is common place now days) go with Chromecast Ultra or as I would recommend, a different brand entirely.

author: Tyler

review_text: I bought this because my laptop's HDMI port doesn't work—what a mistake!The stream quality is atrocious. It's like watching a YouTube video in 2007. The resolution drops off a cliff from your computer to the TV, and the framerate goes up and down, at some points freezing a single frame onto the TV for several seconds.Theoretically you should be able to improve the picture quality by streaming a *file* instead of your computer screen to the TV, but only files that are natively supported in Google Chrome can be streamed, and this excludes such "rare" filetypes as .mkv. I tried several Chrome extensions and other methods to get around this, but sure enough, Chrome thwarted me at every turn.If at all possible, please just buy an HDMI cord.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 19, 2020

review_text: Truly, one of the worst technology purchases of my lifetime. My hatred for this device is the peak of first-world problems: I have to get up and unplug this thing every time I want to watch something new.It constantly disconnects from the app I’m watching half way through any show or movie. Netflix? Yep. Comcast? Yep. Disney+? Yep. It continues playing on my TV but disconnects from my phone and can’t be found to change the show or app.I’m using the Google Home app on my iPhone but it won’t reset there as it’s disconnected from Wifi, of course, because if the Disney+ or whatever app can’t find it the Google Home app won’t find it. So having to get up and reset this every time makes this a complete waste of time, money and energy.
